[[File:The CP24 Truck.jpg|thumb|right|250px|CTV's signage on [[299 Queen Street West]] accompanied by the [[Olympic rings]], signifying the network's role as flagship broadcaster]]Established in 2007,<ref>[http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/February2009/09/c6937.html]</ref> '''Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium''' (legal name ''7048467 Canada Inc.'', also sometimes referred to informally in branding as '''CTV Olympics''' and '''RDS Olympiques''') was a [[joint venture]] set up by Canadian [[mass media|media]] companies [[Bell Media]] (formerly [[CTVglobemedia]]) and [[Rogers Media]] to produce the Canadian broadcasts of the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] in [[Vancouver|Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada, and the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, England, as well as the two corresponding [[Paralympic Games]]. Bell owned 80% of the joint venture, and Rogers owned 20%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellmediapr.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=13117&yyyy=2010|title=Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium Wins Seven Gemini Awards for Esteemed Coverage of Vancouver 2010 Olympic Winter Games|author=Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium|date=2010-11-03|accessdate=2011-04-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727114324/http://www.bellmediapr.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=13117&yyyy=2010|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref>
The consortium encompassed many of the properties owned by both companies, including Bell Media's [[CTV Television Network]], [[The Sports Network|TSN]], [[Réseau des Sports|RDS]] and [[RDS Info]], and Rogers Media's [[Omni Television]], [[Sportsnet]], [[OLN]], and the Rogers radio stations group. Several other broadcasters will carried consortium coverage, including [[V (TV network)|V]] (formerly TQS), and several channels owned by [[Asian Television Network]]. Finally, dedicated websites in English and French (''ctvolympics.ca'' and ''rdsolympiques.ca'') were set up to stream live coverage over the [[Internet]] to Canadian viewers. The consortium replaced [[CBC Sports]], which had held the Canadian rights to all Olympics beginning with the [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996 games]], although some cable rights had been sub-licensed to TSN / RDS beginning in 1998.
Rogers announced in September 2011 that it would withdraw from the consortium following London 2012, and therefore not participate in its bid for rights to the [[2014 Winter Olympics]] and [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. The company cited scheduling conflicts and financial considerations for the decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/September2011/08/c9399.html|title=Rogers Media Withdraws from Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium in Bid for 2014/16 Olympic Games|author=[[Rogers Media]]|date=2011-09-08|accessdate=2011-09-09}}</ref> Bell Media then announced a new partnership with the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] to bid for Canadian [[broadcasting rights]] of Sochi 2014 and Rio 2016. Broadcast details for the joint bid were never released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/September2011/09/c9855.html|title=Bell Media and CBC/Radio-Canada to Jointly Bid for Sochi 2014 and Rio 2016 Olympic Games|author=[[Bell Media]] and [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=2011-09-09|accessdate=2011-09-09}}</ref> The joint Bell/CBC bid was considered the prohibitive favourite to win the rights when the [[International Olympic Committee]] accepted bids.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/bell-media-cbc-partner-for-olympic-bid/article2159515/|title=Bell Media, CBC partner for Olympic bid|first=Susan|last=Krashinsky|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2011-09-09|accessdate=2011-09-09}}</ref> However, the Bell/CBC bids were rejected by the IOC.
On August 1, 2012, CBC Sports announced that it had made a deal to broadcast the 2014 and 2016 Summer and Winter Olympics, replacing the Bell/Rogers group.<ref name=cbc-returns>{{cite web|title=CBC wins rights to 2014, 2016 Olympic Games|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2012/08/01/cbc-olympics-rights.html|publisher=CBC Sports|accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref> However, in February 2013, CBC announced that both Sportsnet and TSN would sub-license broadcast rights to the 2014 Winter Olympics.<ref name=sn-sochi>{{cite web|title=Sportsnet to air 200 hours of Sochi Games|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/olympics/2013/02/07/sportsnet_reaches_olympic_sub_license_deal/|publisher=[[Sportsnet]]|accessdate=8 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213143302/http://www.sportsnet.ca/olympics/2013/02/07/sportsnet_reaches_olympic_sub_license_deal/#|archive-date=2013-02-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=cbc-2014coverage>{{cite web|title=CBC/Radio Canada welcomes partners in 2014 Sochi Olympics coverage|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/olympics/story/2013/02/07/sp-cbc-sports-sochi-olympics-tv-coverage.html|publisher=CBC|accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref>
==Participating media outlets==
===Television=== *Primary coverage (live coverage of major events, and highlights of all events) was carried on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] (English) and [[V (TV network)|V]] (French). **As there is no full-time CTV affiliate in [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], coverage was simulcast on Bell-owned [[CTV Two Atlantic]], which is available on cable in Newfoundland (in other areas, [[CTV Two]] carried normal programming). During the 2010 Winter Olympics, over-the-air station [[CJON-TV|NTV]] carried only the opening and closing ceremonies, and coverage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's hockey gold medal game]]. **V's coverage was produced by RDS<ref name="2010-coverage" /> and mostly used that channel's talent, as V has no in-house production staff for news or sports. Similarly, most hosts for CTV's coverage came from TSN. **Since V has limited coverage outside Quebec, its coverage of the 2010 games was simulcast on the [[Cable Public Affairs Channel]] (CPAC), which has mandatory carriage on all cable and satellite providers.<ref>[http://cpac.ca/forms/index.asp?dsp=template&act=view3&section_id=21&template_id=1302&lang=e CPAC and CTV Team Up to Deliver French Olympic Coverage], CPAC / COBMC press release, 2010-02-11</ref> *Secondary coverage (full events and some highlights between events) aired primarily on [[The Sports Network|TSN]] and [[Sportsnet]] (English), as well as [[Réseau des sports|RDS]] and [[RDS Info]] (French). Select TSN coverage was rebroadcast later on [[TSN2]]. [[OLN]] (English) also provided full-event coverage of selected outdoor events. *Multilingual coverage on various [[Omni Television]] stations: **[[CFMT-DT|Omni.1 (Ontario)]] only: Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Ukrainian **[[CJMT-DT|Omni.2 (Ontario)]], [[CJEO-DT|Omni Edmonton]], [[CJCO-DT|Omni Calgary]], [[CHNM-DT|Omni British Columbia]]: Cantonese, Mandarin **Omni BC only: Punjabi *Multilingual coverage on seven [[Asian Television Network]] channels: **[[ATN Bangla (Canada)|ATN Bangla]] ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]) **[[ATN Gujarati]] ([[Gujarati language|Gujarati]]) **[[ATN Channel]] ([[Hindi]]) **[[ATN Alpha ETC Punjabi]] and [[ATN MH1]] ([[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]) **[[ATN Jaya TV]] ([[Tamil language|Tamil]]) **[[ATN ARY Digital]] ([[Urdu]]) *[[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|APTN]] provided coverage of the 2010 games in several native languages; including ([[Cree]], [[Dene]], [[Inuktitut]], [[Michif language|Mechif]], [[Mi'kmaq]], [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]], [[Ojibwe language|Ojibway]] and [[Oji-Cree]]). In some cases the network was split, with commentary in two or three different languages on the East, West, and North feeds. It also aired some English and French coverage as an overflow channel. APTN did not participate in coverage for the 2012 Summer Olympics.
===Radio=== *English-language radio coverage aired over Rogers's [[Sportsnet Radio|Sportsnet Radio Network]]. Ten Rogers stations, namely "Sportsnet Radio" ([[CJCL]] Toronto and [[CFAC]] Calgary), all-news or news/talk stations ([[CKWX]] Vancouver, [[CFTR (AM)|CFTR]] Toronto, [[CFFR]] Calgary, [[CKGL]] Kitchener, [[CHNI-FM]] Saint John, [[CJNI-FM]] Halifax, and [[CKNI-FM]] Moncton), as well as [[CISQ-FM]] Whistler, were listed as "official" Consortium stations and typically air most if not all coverage. Portions of the coverage aired on other [[Rogers Media]] radio stations, as well as several other stations in non-competing markets (such as CTV-owned [[CKGM]] [[Montreal]]). *[[French-language]] radio coverage of the 2010 games was aired on Cogeco radio stations, primarily airing on [[CKAC]] Montreal (then an all-sports station). No similar coverage plans were announced for the 2012 games.
===Other affiliated outlets=== *Several other Bell Media-owned channels, such as [[CTV News Channel (Canada)|CTV News Channel]] and [[Discovery Channel (Canada)|Discovery Channel]]) provided ancillary (non-event) coverage related to the games. CTV-owned music channel [[MuchMusic]] broadcast programming live from the Vancouver area throughout the 2010 games, including special editions of ''[[MuchOnDemand]]'' broadcast from Whistler. *''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', a national newspaper which was owned by CTVglobemedia at the time of the Vancouver games (and is currently 15% owned by Bell Media's parent company), was listed as part of the consortium and supplied content for its websites, however its sponsorship/coverage of the games is independent of the broadcast rights.
==History==
===Early coverage=== {{Split section|discuss=Talk:Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium#Olympics on CTV before Vancouver games|date=March 2018}} CTV has previously broadcast the Summer Games in [[1976 Summer Games|1976]] (along with CBC) and [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992]], and the Winter Games in [[1964 Winter Olympics|1964]], [[1968 Winter Olympics|1968]], [[1972 Winter Olympics|1972]], [[1976 Winter Olympics|1976]], [[1980 Winter Olympics|1980]], [[1984 Winter Olympics|1984]], [[1988 Winter Olympics|1988]] and [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994]].
The 1980 "[[Miracle on Ice]]" game was aired live on CTV in Canada, but not [[Olympics on ABC|ABC]] in the United States. Thus, American viewers who resided in or near the Canada–US border and received the CTV signal could watch the game live, but the rest of the United States had to wait for a delayed rebroadcast.
====Rights fees==== In 1974, [[Johnny Esaw]] (who anchored CTV's prime time Olympic coverage from 1964–1980) became vice-president of CTV Sports, a position he would hold until his retirement in 1990. He negotiated the host broadcasting rights to the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary, Alberta]]. As the main host broadcaster for the 1988 Winter Olympics, the CTV television network paid $45 million for domestic rights to the 1988 Winter Olympics. Esaw also brought the [[1964 Winter Olympics]] to CTV.
Production of the broadcasting for the 1994 Winter Olympics in [[Lillehammer, Norway]], which costs NOK 462 million,<ref>LOOC (I): 30</ref> was the responsibility of the [[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] (NRK), with assistance from CTV and the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU).<ref>LOOC (II): 206</ref> NRK had 1,424 people working at the Olympics, while international broadcasters sent an additional 4,050 accredited broadcasting personnel. The transmission rights for the games were held by EBU in Europe, [[Olympics on CBS|CBS]] in the United States, [[NHK]] in Japan, CTV in Canada, the [[Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union]], [[Nine Network]] in Australia, as well as other broadcasters in other countries. The total transmission rights price was 350 million United States dollars.<ref>LOOC (II): 205</ref>
====Commentators==== *[[Rod Black]] anchored CTV's coverage of the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona, Spain]] and [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer, Norway]]. *[[Don Chevrier]] provided [[television network]] coverage of the [[Olympic Games]] for North American audiences since 1972, working for the CBC, the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC), and the [[CTV Television Network]] before moving on to NBC. More recently, he covered events at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]], including [[badminton]], [[table tennis]], and [[synchronized swimming]] for NBC, and, along with longtime partner, [[Don Duguid]], called curling at the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in [[Salt Lake City]] and in the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[Turin]] for NBC. *[[Rob Faulds]] worked on CTV's coverage of the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona, Spain]] and the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer, Norway]]. *[[Dan Kelly (sportscaster)|Dan Kelly]] was the lead play-by-play hockey broadcaster for CTV at the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary]]. *[[Dan Matheson]] hosted the network's coverage of the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary]], the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona]], and the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer]]. *[[Jiggs McDonald]] did play-by-play on CTV for [[Basketball at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Olympic basketball]] games in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Legends – Media Honourees: Foster Hewitt Memorial Award Winners |publisher=Hockey Hall of Fame |url=http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/leg_broadcasters.htm |accessdate=2010-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705232153/http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/leg_broadcasters.htm |archivedate=2010-07-05 |df= }}</ref> *[[Greg Millen]] paired with [[Don Chevrier]] as the lead broadcasting team for CTV's ice hockey coverage at the [[ice hockey at the 1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Winter Olympics]]. The secondary team was [[Dan Shulman]] and [[Tom Watt]]. *[[Valerie Pringle]] was a host of special events programming such as the network's [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 election]] and [[1995 Quebec referendum]] coverage and the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer, Norway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capebretonpost.com/Hockey/2010-02-08/article-837142/Fifteen-years-after-Lillehammer-CTV-set-to-tackle-Vancouver-Winter-Games/1 |title=Fifteen years after Lillehammer, CTV set to tackle Vancouver Winter Games |date=8 February 2010 |work=Cape Breton Post |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69ED0Tph7?url=http://www.capebretonpost.com/Hockey/2010-02-08/article-837142/Fifteen-years-after-Lillehammer-CTV-set-to-tackle-Vancouver-Winter-Games/1 |archivedate=17 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Ron Reusch]] covered the [[1980 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]] ([[ice hockey at the 1980 Winter Olympics|ice hockey]]), the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary, Alberta]] ([[ice hockey at the 1988 Winter Olympics|ice hockey]]), the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] in [[Barcelona, Spain]] ([[baseball at the 1992 Summer Olympics|baseball]]), and the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lillehammer, Norway]] ([[speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics|speed skating]]). *[[Frank Rigney]] was the colour commentator for both the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] and [[CFL on CTV|CTV football broadcasts]], plus covered other sports such as the [[1980 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]] and the [[1984 Winter Olympics]] in [[Sarajevo]], [[Yugoslavia]]. *[[Lloyd Robertson]] was the prime time anchor for CTV's coverage in [[1984 Winter Olympics|1984]] and [[1988 Winter Olympics|1988]].

====Television==== [[File:CTV broadcasting team.jpg|thumb|right|The Consortium's studio panel for men's hockey, at [[Canada Hockey Place]] (from left: [[James Duthie (sportscaster)|James Duthie]], [[Darren Pang]], [[Nick Kypreos]], and [[Bob McKenzie (broadcaster)|Bob McKenzie]])]] Consortium coverage originated primarily from the [[Vancouver Convention Centre]] (the [[International Broadcast Centre]] for the 2010 games) as well as Mountain Square in [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]].
*CTV: An average of 22 hours per day of coverage, focusing on the major events and highlights. ''Times varied on certain days depending on events in progress'' **''Olympic Morning'': 3:00-9:00am PT (6:00-12:00pm ET), with [[Beverly Thomson]], [[Jay Onrait]], [[Seamus O'Regan]], and [[Melissa Grelo]] **''Olympic Daytime'': 9:00am–2:30pm PT (12:00-5:30pm ET), with [[James Duthie (sportscaster)|James Duthie]], [[Lisa LaFlamme]], and [[Michael Landsberg]] **''Olympic Prime Time'': 3:00-11:00pm PT (6:00-2:00am ET), with [[Brian Williams (sportscaster)|Brian Williams]] and [[Jennifer Hedger]] **''Olympic Late Night'': Midnight to 3:00am PT (3:00-6:00am ET), no host (event repeats)
:The only breaks in coverage were for 30-minute local newscasts daily at 2:30 pm PT (5:30 pm ET), as well as a one-hour newscast produced by [[CIVT-TV|CTV British Columbia]] at 11:00pm PT (2:00 am ET). Two ''[[CTV National News]]'' summaries, anchored by [[Lloyd Robertson]] at CTV's [[750 Burrard Street|main Vancouver studios]], were aired nightly during ''Olympic Prime Time''; the regular ''CTV National News'' broadcast aired solely on [[CTV News Channel (Canada)|CTV News Channel]] for the duration of the games.<ref>"[http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12058&yyyy=2010 CTV Delivers Canada's #1 News Coverage of Vancouver 2010 Olympic Winter Games] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719081157/http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12058&yyyy=2010# |date=2011-07-19 }}", CTV press release, 2010-01-12</ref> From 3:00 – 6:00am PT (6:00 – 9:00am ET) CTV News Channel also aired a simulcast of CTV's ''Olympic Morning''.
*V: Major events and highlights in French, averaging 16.5 hours per day, including a morning show simulcast from RDS *TSN and Rogers Sportsnet: Full-event coverage, averaging 18 hours per day on each channel *OLN: Full-event coverage of outdoor events, averaging 4.5 hours per day *RDS: Full-event coverage in French, averaging 21 hours per day *RIS: Full-event coverage in French, averaging 6 hours per day *Omni: Multilingual coverage, averaging up to 6 hours per day (depending on location; not all coverage carried on all stations) *ATN: Multilingual coverage, averaging 6.5 hours a day across seven channels *APTN: Coverage in English, French, and Aboriginal languages, averaging 13 hours a day
The television broadcast was filmed with 39 new Hitachi SK-HD1000 studio/field cameras from Hitachi Kokusai Electric including on-site [[technical support]]. The cameras were also used to broadcast the [[2012 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitachikokusai.com/Apps/hitachidenshi/content.jsp?page=portable_production/details/SKHD1000.html&level=2&section=portable_production&parent=details&nav=left&path=/hdal.com/jsp/hitachidenshi/products/broadcast_prof_products/&nId=iD|title=SK-HD1000|publisher=Hitachi Kokusai Electric America, Ltd.|accessdate=2010-03-04}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Following the games, portions of CTV's set were re-purposed by its Vancouver affiliate [[CIVT-DT|CIVT]] for its newscasts.<ref name=ctvbc-set>{{cite web|title=CTV British Columbia unveils Olympic legacy set|url=http://bc.ctvnews.ca/ctv-british-columbia-unveils-olympic-legacy-set-1.493422|publisher=CTV News|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>

==Other rights==
===Paralympic Games=== The consortium also owned rights to the corresponding [[Paralympic Games]], namely the [[2010 Winter Paralympics]] and the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]].
Coverage for the 2010 games consisted primarily of coverage of the opening ceremonies (live on [[CIVT-TV|CTV British Columbia]], and on tape delay on the rest of the CTV network and RIS); daily highlights packages split among CTV, TSN and Sportsnet in English (and RDS / RIS in French); and live coverage of all [[Ice sledge hockey at the 2010 Winter Paralympics|sledge hockey]] games featuring the Canadian team.<ref>[http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12356&yyyy=2010 Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium Reveals Broadcast Plans for Vancouver 2010 Paralympic Winter Games, March 12-21] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314053351/http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12356&yyyy=2010# |date=2010-03-14 }}, COBMC press release, 2010-03-08</ref> Although not originally scheduled, CTV and RDS later added live coverage of the closing ceremonies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12390&yyyy=2010 |title=Closing Ceremony of 2010 Paralympic Winter Games To Air Live on CTV and RDS, This Sunday |publisher=Canada's Olympic Broadcast Media Consortium (press release) |date=2010-03-16 |accessdate=2010-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719081607/http://www.ctvmedia.ca/olympics/releases/release.asp?id=12390&yyyy=2010 |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref>
Coverage for the 2012 games offered no live television coverage and consisted primarily of 10 late night highlight shows carried on [[TSN2]], [[Sportsnet One]], and [[RDS2]], though rebroadcasts of the opening ceremony were carried on both CTV and Rogers-owned broadcast network [[Citytv]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.ca/en/London-2012/London-2012-News/Follow-Your-Team-Canadian-Paralympic-Committee-Announces-Complete-Broadcast-Schedule-of-2012-Paralympic-Games-Coverage.html|title=FOLLOW YOUR TEAM: CANADIAN PARALYMPIC COMMITTEE ANNOUNCES COMPLETE BROADCAST SCHEDULE OF 2012 PARALYMPIC GAMES COVERAGE|author=[[Canadian Paralympic Committee]]|date=2012-08-23|accessdate=2012-08-31|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130115115916/http://www.paralympic.ca/en/London-2012/London-2012-News/Follow-Your-Team-Canadian-Paralympic-Committee-Announces-Complete-Broadcast-Schedule-of-2012-Paralympic-Games-Coverage.html#|archive-date=2013-01-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.citytv.com/schedule/toronto/day/?date=2012-08-31|title=Citytv Toronto Program Schedule – August 31, 2012|accessdate=2012-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CDNParalympics/status/241634267367620610|title=Tweet from the Canadian Paralympic Committee|work=[[Twitter]]|date=2012-08-31|accessdate=2012-08-31}}</ref>
====Criticism of Paralympic Games coverage====
=====2010 Winter Paralympics opening and closing ceremonies===== Originally, CTV did not plan to air the [[2010 Winter Paralympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] live. After receiving criticism on the decision, CTV changed its mind and decided to air the ceremony live in Vancouver region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportscastermagazine.ca/on-air/ctv-vancouver-to-air-paralympic-opening-ceremonies/1000363892/ |title=CTV Vancouver To Air Paralympic Opening Ceremonies |publisher=The Sports Broadcasting Magazine |date=March 12, 2010}}</ref> CTV originally continued to stick to its initial plan of not airing the [[2010 Winter Paralympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] live. This decision led to more complaints and CTV relented by airing the closing ceremony live across Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/article-298096/vancouver/ctv-decides-broadcast-paralympic-closing-ceremony-live |title=CTV decides to broadcast Paralympic closing ceremony live |publisher=The Georgia Straight |date=March 16, 2010}}</ref>
=====2012 Summer Paralympics===== Despite the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] being a breakthrough games for international media coverage, giving a significant boost to the overall audience shares of British broadcaster [[Channel 4]] and Australia's [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/1148995/Paralympics-coverage-changed-disability-perceptions-says-C4/ | title=Paralympics coverage changed disability perceptions, says C4|author=Media Week|date=2012-09-10|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/media/paralympics-a-ratings-winner-for-abc/story-e6frg996-1226472161772 | title=Paralympics a ratings winner for ABC|author=[[The Australian]]|date=2012-09-12|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref> no Paralympics sports events were shown live on television in Canada or the United States. "Based on the level of overall coverage, it's clear that Canadian broadcasters do not deem disability to be important. They are not supporters of inclusion", SCI BC ([[BC Paraplegic Association]]) Executive Director Chris McBride said, contrasting Canada's coverage with Britain's.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sci-bc.ca/news/put-the-paralympics-on-tv/ | title=Put the Paralympics on TV!|author=SCI BC|date=2012-09-18|accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> More than 1,000 people signed a petition calling for Canadian broadcasters to provide full Paralympics coverage at future Games. [[International Paralympic Committee]] President [[Philip Craven]] criticised North American broadcasters for having fallen behind<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/paralympic-sport/9509190/NBC-criticised-Paralympics-after-opening-ceremony-blackout.html/ | title=NBC criticised Paralympics after opening ceremony blackout|author=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2012-08-30|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref> and said in future the International Paralympic Committee would scrutinize broadcast partners more carefully. "If the values fit, we've got a chance. If they don't we'll go somewhere else", he said.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19544410/ | title=Extra scrutiny for Paralympic TV deals|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2012-09-10|accessdate=2012-09-13}}</ref>
===Youth Olympics=== Finally, the consortium owned broadcast rights to the first [[Youth Olympic Games]], the [[2010 Summer Youth Olympics]] in [[Singapore]]. Coverage of those games was limited to a one-hour daily highlights package on [[Sportsnet]] and [[TSN2]] (rebroadcast several weeks later on TSN).

{{orphan|date=August 2014}} The '''center of government''' (CoG) is the institution or group of institutions that provide direct support to the chief executive (president or prime minister) in leading the management of government.<ref name=CoGP> {{cite web |title=Center of Government Project |publisher=Inter-American Development Bank |url=http://www.iadb.org/en/topics/government/strengthening-the-center-of-government-cog,9091.html }}</ref> Unlike line ministries and other government agencies, the CoG does not deliver services directly to the citizens, and it does not focus on a specific policy area.<ref> {{cite report |last1=James|first1=S. |first2=M.|last2=Ben-Gera |year=2004 |title=A Comparative Analysis of Government Offices in OECD Countries |location=París:publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] |url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/cafrad/unpan024508.pdf }}</ref> On the contrary, the CoG performs cross-government functions. A similar concept is "Core Executive".<ref name="Core Executive Studies in Britain">{{cite report |last1=Dunleavy|first1=P. |first2=R.A.|last2=Rhodes |year=1990 |title=Core Executive Studies in Britain |publisher=Public Administration |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9299.1990.tb00744.x/abstract }}</ref>
== Definition == Two types of CoG definition exist: by structure or by function.<ref name=IADB-Role> {{cite report |last1=Alessandro|first1=M. |first2=M.|last2=Lafuente |first3=C.|last3=Santiso |year=2013 |title=The Role of the Center of Government: A Literature Review |location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=[[Inter-American Development Bank]] |url=http://www.iadb.org/en/publications/publication-detail,7101.html?id=70624 }}</ref>
In the first type, the defining criterion is the position in the structure of the Executive branch. It only includes institutions and units that directly and exclusively support the head of the government. For example, it refers to Ministries or General-Secretariats of the Presidency, Offices of the President or Prime Minister, and Cabinet Offices.
In the functional definitions, the defining criterion is that the institution performs whole-of-government functions, especially in terms of planning, coordination, monitoring, political management, and communications. Therefore, in addition to the previously mentioned institutions (such as Ministries of the Presidency), other institutions performing these tasks are also included, even if they are not part of the structure of the Presidency. For example, Ministries or Offices of Planning, [[:en:Prime Minister's Delivery Unit|Delivery Units]], Inter-Ministerial Committees, and even Budget Offices are considered part of the CoG.
A number of authors favor functional definitions, for considering them more applicable to countries with different forms of government and institutional frameworks.<ref name="Core Executive Studies in Britain"/><ref name=IADB-Strength> {{cite report |last1=Alessandro|first1=M. |first2=M.|last2=Lafuente |first3=C.|last3=Santiso |year=2013 |title=Strengthening the Center of Government in Latin America and the Caribbean |docket=Technical Note Nro. IDB-TN-591. |location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=Inter-American Development Bank |url=http://www.iadb.org/en/publications/publication-detail,7101.html?id=71041 }}</ref>
== Relevance ==
Chief Executives (Presidents and Prime Ministers) have had supporting institutions for a long time. In the United Kingdom, the [[:en:Cabinet Office|Cabinet Office]] dates to 1916, when the war demanded a stronger central coordination for the government.<ref> {{cite report |author=House of Commons Library |year=2005 |title=The Centre of Government - No. 10, the Cabinet Office and HM Treasury |docket=Research Paper 05/92 |location=London|publisher=[[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] |url=http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/RP05-92.pdf }}</ref> In the United States, the [[Executive Office of the President of the United States|Executive Office of the President]] was established in 1939, after the [[:en:Brownlow Committee|Brownlow Committee]] stated that "the President needs help."<ref> {{cite report |last=Relyea|first=H. |year=2008 |title=The Executive Office of the President: an Historical Overview |location=Washington, DC|publisher=Congressional Research Service |url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/98-606.pdf }}</ref> Offices, Ministries or General Secretariats of the Presidency have also existed in Latin American for several decades now.<ref name=IADB-Role/>
However, a number of factors lead to a greater importance of the CoG. The following factors have been highlighted: the cross-cutting nature of several current public problems,<ref> {{cite report |last1=Clarke|first1=M. |first2=J.|last2=Stewart |year=1997 |title=Handling the Wicked Issues: A Challenge for Government |docket=INLOGOV Discussion Paper |location=Birmingham|publisher=University of Birmingham }}</ref> the need to lead with a unified orientation governments that have decentralized authority to autonomous agencies,<ref> {{cite book |last1=Dahlström|first1=C. |first2=G.|last2=Peters |first3=J.|last3=Pierre |year=2011 |title=Steering from the Centre. Strengthening Political Control in Western Democracies |location=Toronto|publisher=University of Toronto Press }}</ref> and the growing interesting for achieving results for the citizens, beyond a purely fiscal coordination.<ref name=IADB-Strength/> These factors explain the interest that several governments and international organizations have on the topic, including projects by the [[OECD|Organisation for Cooperation and Economic Development]]<ref> {{cite web |title=Network of Senior Officials from Centers of Government |url=http://www.oecd.org/gov/cog.htm }}</ref> and the [[Inter-American Development Bank]].<ref name=CoGP/>
Moreover, new institutional developments have generated increased interest in the CoG. The [[:en:Prime Minister's Delivery Unit|Prime Minister's Delivery Unit]] in the United Kingdom was established to ensure that the government's priorities were being implemented, through an intensive monitoring by the CoG. Several countries have replicated this model,<ref> {{cite report |author=World Bank |year=2010 |title=GET Note: Center of Government Delivery Units |location=Washington, DC|publisher=World Bank |url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTGOVANTICORR/Resources/3035863-1285601351606/NovemberGetNote.pdf }}</ref> including Malaysia<ref> {{cite journal |last=McCourt|first=W. |year=2012 |title=Can Top-Down and Bottom-Up be Reconciled? Electoral Competition and Service Delivery in Malaysia |journal=World Development |volume=40|number=11 |doi=10.1016/j.worlddev.2012.03.023 |url=http://ideas.repec.org/a/eee/wdevel/v40y2012i11p2329-2341.html |pages=2329–2341 }}</ref> and Chile.<ref> {{cite journal |last1=Dumas|first1=V. |last2=Lafuente|first2=M. |last3=Parrado|first3=S. |year=2013 |title=Strengthening the Center of Government for Results in Chile: The Experience of the Ministry of the Presidency and its President's Delivery Unit (2010-13) |docket=Technical Note Nro. IDB-TN-563. |location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=Inter-American Development Bank |url=http://www.iadb.org/en/publications/publication-detail,7101.html?id=70216 }}</ref> Paraguay has established a "Center of Government" within the General-Secretariat of the Presidency, in charge of coordinating and monitoring the government action.<ref>{{cite report |author = Presidencia de la República de Paraguay |title = Decreto 1214/2014 |url = http://www.gacetaoficial.gov.py/gaceta.php?action=show&id=2275&num=43 |date = |access-date = 2014-03-12 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140312225314/http://www.gacetaoficial.gov.py/gaceta.php?action=show&id=2275&num=43# |archivedate = 2014-03-12 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
== The center of government in different countries == In OECD countries, the CoG institutions lead the functions of coordinating the preparation of Cabinet meetings, coordinating the formulation and implementation of policy, monitoring delivery, strategic planning for the whole-of-government, and communicating the government's messages.<ref name=IADB-Centre> {{cite conference |last=Alter |first=Rolf |title=The Centre of Government: a strategic governance response to economic and social challenges? |conference=International Seminar Center of Government and Governability, IDB-UC, Santiago |url=http://politicaspublicas.uc.cl/cpp/static/uploads/adjuntos_seminarios/adjuntos_seminario.archivo_adjunto.9009f8fd032b3472.50726573656e74616369c3b36e20526f6c6620416c7465722e706466.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312001019/http://politicaspublicas.uc.cl/cpp/static/uploads/adjuntos_seminarios/adjuntos_seminario.archivo_adjunto.9009f8fd032b3472.50726573656e74616369c3b36e20526f6c6620416c7465722e706466.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-12 |df= }}</ref> Regarding the characteristics of the CoG, there are important variations in terms of organization and staff. For example, in countries like the United Kingdom and Sweden most of the CoG staff belongs to the civil service, while in Canada, Australia and New Zealand political appointees have a larger presence.<ref> {{cite report |last1=Truswell|first1=E. |first2=D.|last2=Atkinson |year=2011 |title=Supporting Heads of Government. A Comparison across Six Countries |location=London|publisher=Institute for Government |url=http://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/sites/default/files/publications/Supporting%20Heads%20of%20Government.pdf }}</ref> Important variations have also been identified in Latin America, not only in terms of organization but also in the capacity of CoGs to perform their functions: while some countries have more developed CoGs, others present more serious weaknesses.<ref name=IADB-Strength/> This heterogeneity across countries has also been detected in the Middle East and North Africa region.<ref> {{cite report |last1=Haddad|first1=C. |first2=M.|last2=Klouche |first3=Y.|last3=Heneine |year=2010 |title=Center of Government. The Engine of Modern Public Institutions |location=New York, NY|publisher=Strategy& (formerly Booz & Company) |url=http://www.strategyand.pwc.com/global/home/what-we-think/reports-white-papers/article-display/center-government-engine-modern-public }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== See also == * [http://www.oecd.org/gov/cog.htm OECD Network of Senior Officials from Centres of Government] * [http://www.iadb.org/en/topics/government/strengthening-the-center-of-government-cog,9091.html Website of the Center of Government Project of the Inter-American Development Bank]

[[File:Le_Bon_Pasteur_Philippe_de_Champaigne.jpg|thumb|right|325px|[[Depictions of Jesus]] have often shown him in terms of animal-related imagery such as that of the '[[good shepherd]]', an example being this [[16th century]] work by [[Philippe de Champagne]].]]
The relationship between '''[[Christianity]] and [[animal rights]]''' has been a complex one that's varied greatly depending on the historical context, with different Christian communities in different nations coming to very different conclusions. The matter is closely related to, but still distinct from and broader than, efforts by [[Christian vegetarians]] as well as [[Christian environmentalists]]. Majority viewpoints in many nations have held that animals must be treated humanely beyond mere [[inanimate]] objects, yet the details of how exactly to do so have remained under dispute.
Many Christian [[philosophers]] and socio-political figures have stated that individuals should follow the example of [[Jesus]] and treat animals in a way that expresses both [[compassion]] as well demonstrates the respectful stewardship of [[Human|humanity]] over the [[Natural environment|environment]]. [[William Wilberforce]], a co-founder of the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]], is an example. Large organizations in which a variety of different groups work together, such as the [[Humane Society of the United States]], have undergone religious outreach using such arguments.<ref name=Scholars/>
Animal rights activists such as Peter Singer have argued that some Christians in the past and present have been either neglectful or dismissive of the causes for animal rights. Others however, have noted that it would be wrong to see Christianity as an enemy on this since Christian theology, like all other religious traditions, has some unique insights to viewing animal life as having fundamental value.<ref name=Satya/> Various church founders have recommended vegetarianism, such as [[William Cowherd]] from the [[Bible Christian Church (vegetarian)|Bible Christian Church]] and [[Ellen G. White]] from the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh-day Adventists]].<ref name=desc>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivu.org/history/thesis/bible-christian.html|title=The Bible Christian Church|publisher=International Vegetarian Union|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Vegetarian America: A History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0AiAz62C_jcC&pg=PA97 |page=97|author=Karen Iacobbo|author2=Michael Iacobbo|year=2004}}</ref> Willaim Cowherd helped to establish the world's first [[Vegetarian Society]] in 1847.<ref name=history>{{cite web|url=http://www.vegsoc.org/page.aspx?pid=827|title=History of Vegetarianism - Early Ideas|publisher=The Vegetarian Society|accessdate=2008-07-08}}; Gregory, James (2007) ''Of Victorians and Vegetarians''. London: I. B. Tauris pp. 30–35.</ref> Christian denominations like Seventh Day Adventists have central vegetarian doctrines incorporated.<ref name="advent" /> John Wesley, the founder of [[Methodism]] also recommended vegetarianism and helped establish the American Vegetarian Society in 1850.<ref name="Veg hand" />
The rise of Christianity put an end to animal sacrificing.<ref name="DeMello2012" /> And references to peaceful co-existence of creatures such as lambs and wolves in the world to come are found in the Bible.<ref name="Souls" />
==Background and details==
===Biblical context=== {{expand section|date=October 2015}}
[[Image:Isaiah scroll.PNG|thumb|250px|right|This image shows the [[Book of Isaiah]], written in its original [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], on a scroll.]]
The role of animals in the [[Bible]] states that any questions of the relationships between animals and people, is a complex one. As remarked by Christian writer Jack Zavada, "Most interpreters of the Bible assume that man’s likeness to God and animals’ subservience to man implies that animals may have the 'breath of life', ''nephesh chay'' in Hebrew, but not an immortal soul in the same sense as man’s."
The book of [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] describes humanity as being made in God's image as well as being given general dominion over the other beings of [[Earth|the earth]]. No mention is made of [[Adam and Eve]] consuming animal flesh, nor of them in any way harming animals through ill treatment.<ref name=Souls>{{cite web|url=http://christianity.about.com/od/whatdoesthebiblesay/f/animalsinheaven.htm|title=Do Animals Have Souls?|publisher=[[About.com]]|first=Jack|last=Zavada|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref> The creatures co-exist in a relationship sense rather than an exploitative one.<ref name=Satya/>
A variety of passages have been cited in support for caring about animal welfare in the broad sense, an example being how [[Book of Proverbs|Proverbs 12:10]] states that a "righteous man cares about his animal's health."
More specifically, [[meat-eating]] and other forms of using some animals for human benefit receive an explicit approval by [[God]] in the aftermath of the events from the expulsion from [[Garden of Eden|Eden]] to the end of the [[Genesis flood narrative|global flood]]. A [[Book of Genesis|Genesis 9:3]] (NIV) section states: "Just as I gave you the green plants, I now give you everything."<ref name=Souls/>
The traditional [[Bible|biblical]] (especially [[Old Testament]]) viewpoint among [[Jews]] and Christians is that God distinguished man from animals, and gave man control over animals to benefit man, but also that God gave man moral guidelines to prevent cruelty to - or needless suffering by - animals.
In particular, [[animal sacrifice]] plays a major role in many sections of the Bible, reflective of [[Ritual slaughter#Jewish and Islamic ritual slaughter|the practice's widespread nature]] in early [[Judaism]]. Specific instances include [[Book of Leviticus|Leviticus 1:2]] (NIV): "Speak to the Israelites and say to them: 'When any of you brings an offering to the Lord, bring as your offering an animal from either the herd or the flock.'"<ref name=Souls/> A consensus viewpoint doesn't exist as to the exact meaning and reasoning behind said sacrifices, even if they have been interpreted as perhaps symbolizing the returning to God the sense of the 'power over life' in reverential tribute to how God served as the maker of creation to begin with. As remarked by theologian [[Andrew Linzey|Rev. Dr. Andrew Linzey]], "there’s no one view of animal sacrifices even by those who practiced it."<ref name=Satya/>
In terms of the [[afterlife]] and the world to come, descriptions of [[heaven]] describe an existence without violence and strife either among non-human animals or in their relationship to people. For example, [[Book of Isaiah|Isaiah 65:25]] (NIV) states: "The wolf and the lamb will feed together, and the lion will eat straw like the ox, but dust will be the serpent’s food. They will neither harm nor destroy on all my holy mountain, says the Lord."<ref name=Souls/> The depiction of how God's ideal new earth will look like can be interpreted as a signal that human beings should minimize violence as much as possible in terms of all animals.<ref name=Satya/>
[[Jesus Christ]] in the [[New Testament]] exists not just as the core theological figure in Christian thought but also as a moral icon to look to as an inspiration in terms of [[Christian ethics]]. Looking at the canonical [[gospels]], Jesus did not directly identify being a vegetarian and did not act like one.<ref name=Satya/> Biblical passages associate Jesus and his followers with [[fishing]], which could be an implied support for meat-eating (at least of that type) specifically.<ref name=Scholars/> In the larger context of animal rights, though, the association of Jesus as a '[[good shepherd]]' character, one taking things so far that "the good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep", establishes a moral theme of those that are stronger and more powerful being willing to sacrifice for the weaker and less powerful, all out of love. This can be taken as inspiration for animal welfare advocacy by modern Christians.<ref name=Satya/>
The rise of Christianity ended animal sacrifice, as Christians believe Jesus died for all the sins of humanity and is often portrayed as the last sacrificial lamb in the New Testament.<ref name="DeMello2012">{{cite book|last=DeMello|first=Margo|title=Animals and Society: An Introduction to Human-Animal Studies|date=18 September 2012|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231526760|page=317|quote=Later, with the rise of Christianity, animal sacrifice ended. Instead, Christians believe that God sacrificed his son Jesus in order to give humankind salvation; this is one of the reasons that Jesus is often represented as a lamb in Christianity.}}</ref>
===Christian perspectives=== {{expand section|date=October 2015}}
{{see also|Christian culture|Christian ethics}}
Various church founders have recommended vegetarianism, such as [[William Cowherd]] from the [[Bible Christian Church (vegetarian)|Bible Christian Church]] and [[Ellen G. White]] from the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh-day Adventists]].<ref name=desc>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivu.org/history/thesis/bible-christian.html|title=The Bible Christian Church|publisher=International Vegetarian Union|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Vegetarian America: A History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0AiAz62C_jcC&pg=PA97 |page=97|author=Karen Iacobbo|author2=Michael Iacobbo|year=2004}}</ref> Cowherd, who founded the Bible Christian Church in 1809, helped to establish the world's first [[Vegetarian Society]] in 1847.<ref name=history>{{cite web|url=http://www.vegsoc.org/page.aspx?pid=827|title=History of Vegetarianism - Early Ideas|publisher=The Vegetarian Society|accessdate=2008-07-08}}; Gregory, James (2007) ''Of Victorians and Vegetarians''. London: I. B. Tauris pp. 30–35.</ref> [[John Wesley]], the founder of [[Methodism]], promoted vegetarianism which helped establish the American Vegetarian Society in 1850.<ref name="Veg hand">{{cite book|last1=Null|first1=Gary|title=The Vegetarian Handbook|date=1996|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|location=New York|isbn=0312144415|page=13}}</ref>
Some Christians denominations such as the Seventh Day Adventists have central vegetarian doctrines that play a role in adherents.<ref name="advent">{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=George|last2=Montenegro|first2=Jose|title=Vegetarianism in Seventh-day Adventism|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199362202.001.0001/acprof-9780199362202-chapter-5|website=Oxford Scholarship Online|publisher=Oxoford University}}</ref>
[[File:Leo Tolstoy 1897, black and white, 37767u.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Leo Tolstoy]], a [[Russian people|Russian]] novelist regarded as one of the greatest writers of all time, has strongly influenced debates on Christian moral thinking, including towards animals.]]
The tradition of [[Christian vegetarianism]] has long been a minority viewpoint among Christian communities, though its history has gone back many decades in religious thought. [[Leo Tolstoy]]’s views, as expressed in things such as his famous 1909 essay about a [[slaughterhouse]], have remained influential for years. Later writers that cite his comments on animal rights include Catholic columnist [[Mary Eberstadt]].<ref name=Scholars/>
The [[Catechism of the Catholic Church]] takes the position that Christians are called to express kindness to the world's creatures in general, and people possess a [[Morality|moral obligation]] to avoid causing unnecessary suffering to animals. [[Meat-eating]] in the context of nourishment is permitted. Examples of [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] figures that have written in favor of animal rights and against [[factory farming]], though not strictly being [[vegetarian]]s themselves, include [[Fordham University]] professor Charles Camosy and the aforementioned columnist Mary Eberstadt. The former wrote the work ''For Love of Animals: Christian Ethics, Consistent Action'' on the subject, which the latter praised while writing for ''[[National Review]]''.<ref name=Scholars/>
Opinions within the [[Church of England]] have drawn influence from the work of seminal Anglican theologian [[Andrew Linzey]], who published ''Animal Rights: A Christian Assessment'' in 1976 while still a student. Labeled by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as having "caused a sensation in Christian circles" from his first book on,<ref name=Scholars/> he's a member of the faculty at the [[University of Oxford]] as well as the founder and director of the [[Oxford Centre for Animal Ethics]], an independent academic organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordanimalethics.com/who-we-are/director/|title=Director - Oxford Centre for Animal Ethics|website=www.oxfordanimalethics.com}}</ref>
In 1992, [[Anglican]] figures arguing in support of taking a stance against animal cruelty succeeded in having forty-one [[bishops]] signing a pledge not to [[Fur clothing|wear fur]] because of the suffering inflicted, with the pledge getting some attention. However, the debate undertaken by the [[General Synod of the Church of England|General Synod]] in 1990 about both [[hunting]] and factory farming practices done on Church-owned land ended with said practices being allowed to go on.<ref name=Satya>{{cite news|publisher=''Satya''|url=http://www.satyamag.com/feb96/linzey.html|date=February 1996|title=Christianity and Animals: An Interview with Andrew Linzey|first=Rynn|last=Berry|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref>
In terms of the [[Methodism|Methodist tradition]], figures such as [[University of Chester]] professor and author David Clough have held a respect for the rights of animals should exist given that, in Christian terms, God deliberately created the creatures of the world and proclaimed them all as good. He's written that how non-humans are "reconciled to God in Jesus Christ and will be redeemed by God in the new creation" accordingly creates duties for mankind. Besides serving as a Methodist pastor, he's President of the Society for the Study of Christian [[Ethics]].<ref name=Scholars>{{cite news|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=October 6, 2015|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/07/us/exploring-christian-perspectives-on-animal-rights.html|title=Scholars Explore Christian Perspectives on Animal Rights|first=Mark|last=Oppenheimer}}</ref><ref name=Clough>{{cite web|url=http://www.chester.ac.uk/departments/trs/staff/clough|title=Professor David Clough|publisher=[[University of Chester]]|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref>
Bands often labeled as being [[Christian metal]] or influenced by [[Christian music]] such as [[Blessthefall]], [[MyChildren MyBride]], [[Gwen Stacy (band)|Gwen Stacy]], and [[Sleeping Giant (band)|Sleeping Giant]] have had members speak out in favor of animal rights, with those statements garnering attention from secular music-related publications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smnnews.com/2010/02/05/christian-metal-bands-talk-animal-rights/|title=Christian Metal Bands Talk Animal Rights|publisher=}}</ref>
==Secular responses and additional debate== [[File:Peter_Singer_MIT_Veritas.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Philosopher [[Peter Singer]] is pictured here at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT's campus]] speaking in 2009.]]
{{expand section|date=October 2015}} Philosopher [[Peter Singer]] has argued in publications such as his seminal book ''[[Animal Liberation (book)|Animal Liberation]]'', first published in 1975, that Christian thought has contributed to animal cruelty and suffering. He's cited commentary from figures such as [[Aquinas]] about humanity's innate right to control the natural world as holding back progress in animal rights. However, Singer later stated that he had changed his views in part given the complexity of different views towards animals among different Christians.<ref name=Scholars/>
The aforementioned Rev. Dr. Andrew Linzey commented in 1996 that: {{quote|[I]t’s right for animal rights people to be critical and judgmental of the Christian tradition... [which] has been amazingly callous towards animals. Christian theologians have been neglectful and dismissive of the cause of animals— and many still are. Christians and Jews have allowed their ancient texts— such as Genesis— to be read as licensing tyranny over animals... [and] animal rights people sometimes look on Christianity as though it was unambiguously "the enemy." I think it is wrong to write off Christianity in this way. All religious traditions have great resources for a very positive ethic in relation to animals. I would go further and say that however awful the record of Christianity has been, Christian theology has some unique insights fundamental to valuing animal life. From my perspective, without a sense of ultimate meaning and purpose, it is difficult, if not impossible, to justify any kind of moral endeavor... I’m one of those people who believe that morality really depends upon vision.<ref name=Satya/>}}
Contemporary philosopher [[Bernard Rollin]] writes that "''dominion'' does not entail or allow abuse any more than does dominion a parent enjoys over a child."<ref name="Rollin">{{cite book|last=Rollin|first=Bernard E.|title=Animal Rights and Human Morality|publisher=[[Prometheus Books]]|isbn=978-1-61592-211-6|page=117}}<!--|accessdate=3 December 2014--></ref> Rollin further states that the [[Biblical Sabbath]] requirement promulgated in the [[Ten Commandments]] "required that animals be granted a day of rest along with humans. Correlatively, the Bible forbids 'plowing with an ox and an ass together' (Deut. 22:10–11). According to the rabbinical tradition, this prohibition stems from the hardship that an ass would suffer by being compelled to keep up with an ox, which is, of course, far more powerful. Similarly, one finds the prohibition against 'muzzling an ox when it treads out the grain' (Deut. 25:4–5), and even an environmental prohibition against destroying trees when besieging a city (Deut. 20:19–20). These ancient regulations, "bespeak of an eloquent awareness of the status of animals as ends in themselves", a point also corroborated by [[Norm Phelps]].<ref name="Rollin"/><ref name="Phelps2002">{{cite book|last=Phelps|first=Norm|title=Animal Rights According to the Bible|year=2002|publisher=Lantern Books|isbn=978-1-59056-009-9|page=70|quote=The Bible's most important reference to the sentience and will of nonhuman animals is found in Deuteronomy 25:4, which became the scriptural foundation of the rabbinical doctrine of ''tsar ba'ale chayim'', "the suffering of the living," which makes relieving the suffering of animals a religious duty for Jews. "You shall not muzzle the ox while he is threshing." The point of muzzling the ox was to keep him from eating any of the grain that he was threshing. The point of the commandment was the cruelty of forcing an animal to work for hours at a time with his face only inches from delicious food while not allowing him to eat any of it.}}<!--|accessdate=3 December 2014--></ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Christianity|Ethics}} *[[Animal cruelty]] *[[Animal liberation movement]] *[[Christian culture]] *[[Christian ethics]] *[[Christian vegetarianism]] *[[Christianity and environmentalism]] *[[Ethics of eating meat]] *[[Islam and animal rights]] *[[Good Shepherd]] *[[Lamb of God]] *[[Oxford Centre for Animal Ethics]]

{{Unreferenced|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox Software | genre = Law assistance system | name = Consultant Plus | developer = Consultant Plus | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]] | license = Proprietary | website = {{URL|http://www.consultant.ru/}} }} '''Consultant Plus''' ({{lang-ru|Консультант Плюс}}) is an [[Computer-assisted legal research|assistance system]] to work with the legislation of [[Russia]]. Consultant's centralized database is updated daily. It is distributed via a network of partners.
Its major competitors are ''[[Garant]]'' and [[Codex and Techexpert]], both [[proprietary software|proprietary]].
The full federal law database includes over 3 million documents; regional acts are distributed in a separate database with over 4 million documents.
The information contained in the system is structured into several notions, including: # [[legislation]] # [[jurisprudence]] # [[financial advice]]s # legislation commentaries # document forms (templates) # legislation drafts # international legal acts # health protection legal acts # [[technical standard]]s and rules
Every class mentioned above consists of several [[information bank]]s to simplify the search throughout the database by manually excluding the classes and banks inappropriate for each current search.
The database includes: * normative legal acts of Russia and its [[federal subjects of Russia|federal subjects]], as well as international * commentaries and explanations for them, precedents from the common practice * articles and books from periodicals and text collections * forms of account correspondence * forms of the documents (officially standardized and approximate) * other helpful information (accountant calendar, [[exchange rate]]s, [[bank rate]], etc.) * analytical reports
==External links== * [http://www.consultant.ru Official site of Consultant Plus] {{ru icon}} * [http://www.artiks.ru Artiks - Consultant Plus information center web-site] {{ru icon}} * [http://www.consultant.ru/online/ Internet-based version of ConsultantPlus] {{ru icon}} * [http://www.consultant.ru/about/nc/ Non-commercial projects of ConsultantPlus] (for schools, universities, etc.) {{ru icon}} * [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.wKonsultantPlyus Consultant Plus app for Android] {{ru icon}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{See also|Taxation in the Republic of Ireland}} [[File:Charlie McCreevy portrait.jpg|thumb|'''Finance Min. [[Charlie McCreevy]]''' Reduced Irish corporate tax from 32% to 12.5% in the 1999 Finance Act, and whose 1997 Tax and Consolidation Act, laid the framework for Ireland's [[BEPS]] tax tools, the world's largest.]] '''Ireland's Corporate Tax System''' is a central component of Ireland's economy. In 2016–17, foreign firms paid 80% of Irish corporate tax, employed 25% of the Irish labour force (paid 50% of Irish salary tax), and created 57% of Irish OECD non-farm value-add. U.S.–controlled firms represent almost all foreign firms in Ireland and in 2017 were 25 of the top 50 Irish firms, and 70% of the revenue of the top 50 Irish firms ({{slink|#Low tax economy}}). By 2018, Ireland had received the most U.S. {{slink|#Corporate tax inversions}} in history, and Apple was over one–fifth of Irish GDP. Academics rank Ireland as the largest [[tax haven]]; larger than the Caribbean tax haven system.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/ireland-named-as-world-s-biggest-tax-haven-8tx2ngcgj|title=Ireland named as world’s biggest tax haven|publisher=The Times U.K.|date=14 June 2018|quote=Research conducted by academics at the University of California, Berkeley and the University of Copenhagen estimated that foreign multinationals moved €90 billion of profits to Ireland in 2015 — more than all Caribbean countries combined.}} [[File:Apple logo black.svg|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' Ireland's largest company, and over one-fifth of Irish GDP, whose [[Investigation of Apple's transfer pricing arrangements with Ireland|2016 EU €13 billion fine]] on their [[Double Irish]] BEPS scheme is the largest tax fine in history.]] Ireland's "headline" corporation tax rate is 12.5%, however, foreign multinationals pay an {{slink|#Effective tax rate (ETR)}} of under 4% on global profits "shifted" to Ireland, via Ireland's global network of bilateral [[tax treaties]]. These lower effective tax rates are achieved by a complex set of Irish [[base erosion and profit shifting]] ("BEPS") tools which handle the largest BEPS flows in the world (e.g. the '''[[Double Irish]]''' as used by Google and Facebook, the '''[[double Irish arrangement#Replacement by single malt|Single Malt]]''' as used by Microsoft and Allergan, and '''[[double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]''' as used by Accenture, and by Apple post Q1 2015). Ireland's main {{slink|#Multinational tax schemes}} use "[[intellectual property]]" ("IP") accounting to affect the [[BEPS]] movement, which is why almost all foreign multinationals in Ireland are from the industries with substantial IP, namely technology and life sciences. Multinationals from jurisdictions with "territorial tax" systems (i.e. almost all OECD countries), make little use of tax havens, thus, almost most foreign multinationals in Ireland date from periods when their home tax system was a "worldwide tax" system (e.g. UK pre–2009, and U.S. pre–2018); and is why there are no non–U.S./non–UK multinationals in Ireland's top 50 firms. [[File:Ireland Trade Good Discrepancy (1995-2017).png|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' The Q1 2015 restructuring of Apple's non-U.S. IP to Ireland ([[leprechaun economics]]), is the largest [[BEPS]] action in history.
[[Brad Setser]] & Cole Frank ([[Council on Foreign Relations|CoFR]]).]] As with all [[tax havens]], Ireland's GDP is artificially inflated by BEPS accounting flows. This distortion escalated in Q1 2015 when Apple executed the largest BEPS transaction in history, on-shoring $300 billion of non–U.S. IP to Ireland (called "[[leprechaun economics]]"). It forced the [[Central Bank of Ireland]] to abandon GDP in 2017, and replace with [[modified gross national income]] (GNI*), which removes part, but not all, of the distortions by BEPS tools. Irish GDP was 162% of Irish GNI* in 2017.{{efn|name="gnigdp"|In contrast, EU–28 2017 GDP was 100% of EU–28 2017 GNI).}} [[File:Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers Figure 3 Network of ownership flows between countries.jpg|thumb|'''[[Corporate tax haven]]''': Ireland is ranked as one of the largest global [[Conduit and Sink OFCs|Conduit OFCs]] in terms of connections to tax havens, the largest global [[Tax haven#Tax haven lists|Tax Haven]] in terms of quantum of profits shielded, and the 3rd-largest global [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]].]] Ireland's corporation tax regime is integrated with Ireland's [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] tax schemes (e.g. [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPVs]] and [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)|QIAIFs]]), which offer traditional [[tax haven]]-type tools to give confidential routes out of the Irish corporate tax system to Ireland's favoured [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFC]], Luxembourg, which is 50% of all outbound Irish FDI. This functionality has made Ireland one of the largest global [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFCs]], and the third largest global [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]]. Irish privacy and data protection laws hide Irish tax tools from public scrutiny. There is evidence Ireland behaves like a "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Captured state|captured state]]", fostering tax avoidance schemes. Ireland is labelled a {{slink|#Corporate tax haven}}. As {{slink|#Countermeasures to Ireland}}, the U.S. [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] (TCJA) moves the U.S to a "territorial tax" system. The TJCA's GILTI–FDII–BEAT tax regime has seen U.S. IP–heavy multinationals (e.g. Pfizer), forecast 2019 effective tax rates that are similar to those of prior U.S. [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]] to Ireland (e.g. Medtronic). Ireland's corporate tax regime is also threatened by the EU's desire to introduce EU–wide anti-BEPS tool regimes (e.g. the 2020 Digital Services Tax, and the [[Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base|CCCTB]]). ==Tax system== ===Tax rates=== [[File:Irish Corporation Tax Rates (1974 to 2016).png|thumb|Irish corporate tax rates (1974 to 2016). Source: [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]].]] {{See also|#Historical rates (1994–2018)}} {{As of | November 2018}}, there are two rates of corporation tax ("CT") in the Republic of Ireland:{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/invest-in-ireland/ireland-corporate-tax|title=Corporate Tax regime in Ireland|publisher=[[IDA Ireland|Industrial Development Authority]]|date=2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/IDAIreland/media/docs/publications/Taxation_2016.pdf|title=Corporate Taxation in Ireland 2016|publisher=[[IDA Ireland|Industrial Development Authority]]|date=2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/companies-and-charities/corporation-tax-for-companies/corporation-tax/index.aspx|title=Irish Corporation Tax Portal|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=2018}} *a 12.5% ''headline rate''{{efn|name="ETR"|In ''[[#ETR|Effective Tax Rates]]'' it is shown that Ireland's true CT tax rate for foreign multinationals is between 0% to 3% depending on what particular Irish BEPS tools are used. ''[[#ETR|Effective Tax Rates]]'' also shows that the ''aggregate'' CT tax rate in Ireland is between 2% and 4.5% depending on various assumptions.}} for '''trading income''' (or active businesses income in the Irish tax code); ''trading'' relates to conducting a business, not ''investment trading''; *a 25.0% ''headline rate''{{efn|Ireland offers specific Central Bank of Ireland–regulated SPVs that foreign investors in passive Irish income can use avoid the 25% rate (and all other Irish taxes and duties), on Irish assets. The main vehicles are the Irish [[QIAIF]] and the Irish [[Section 110 SPV]]. Public tax scandals in Ireland in 2016, revealed because Irish Section 110 SPVs have to file Irish public accounts, led to the Central Bank of Ireland to introduce the [[L–QIAIF]] vehicle to replace the Section 110 SPV for foreign investors who want to avoid the 25% passive income tax in a confidential manner. QIAIFs and L–QIAIFs do not have to file Irish public accounts; instead filing confidential accounts with the Central Bank of Ireland which are protected under the ''Central Bank Secrecy Act'' of 1942.{{cite web|url= https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/central-bank-secrecy-law-will-limit-public-disclosure-of-key-documents-1.2079188|title=Powerful Central Bank secrecy laws limit public disclosure of key documents|date=January 2016|publisher=Irish Times}}}} for '''non-trading income''' (or also called '''passive income''' in the Irish tax code); covering investment income (e.g. income from buying and selling assets), rental income from real estate, net profits from foreign trades, and income from certain land dealings and income from oil, gas and mineral exploitations in Ireland. ===Key aspects=== [[File:OECD 2018 Corporate Tax Rates.png|thumb|2018 ''headline'' corporate tax rates for all 35 OECD members (pre and post the 2017 U.S [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|TCJA]]).{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/us-corporate-income-tax-more-competitive/|title=The United States’ Corporate Income Tax Rate is Now More in Line with Those Levied by Other Major Nations|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=12 February 2018|author=Kyle Pomerleau}}]] {{As of | November 2018}}, the key attributes that tax experts note regarding the Irish corporate tax system are as follows: * Low headline rate. At 12.5%, Ireland has one of the lowest ''headline''{{efn|name="ETR"}} [[tax rates in Europe]] (Hungary 9% and Bulgaria 10% are lower); OECD average is 24.9%.{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/corporate-income-tax-rates-around-the-world-2017/|title=Lowest and Highest Global Global Corporate Tax Rates|author=Kari Jahnsen|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=September 2017}} * Transparent. Many of Ireland's corporation tax tools are OECD–whitelisted,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-awarded-high-oecd-rating-on-tax-transparency-1.3194255|title=Ireland awarded high OECD rating on tax transparency|publisher=Irish Times|date=22 August 2017}} and Ireland has one of the lowest '''secrecy scores''' in the 2018 [[Financial Secrecy Index|FSI rankings]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/we-have-no-problem-with-irish-tax-system-oecd-36566931.html|title='We have no problem with Irish tax system' - OECD|publisher=Irish Times|date=5 February 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/ireland-does-not-engage-in-harmful-tax-competition-says-european-commission-1.2895658?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fireland-does-not-engage-in-harmful-tax-competition-says-european-commission-1.2895658| title=Ireland does not engage in “harmful tax competition” says European Commission| publisher=Irish Times|date=6 December 2016}} * "Worldwide tax". Ireland is one of 6 remaining countries that use a "worldwide tax" system (Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico).{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/worldwide-taxation-very-rare/|title=Worldwide Taxation is Very Rare|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=February 2015}} * No "thin capitalisation". Ireland has no [[thin capitalisation]] rules, which means that Irish corporates can be financed with 100% debt, and 0% equity.{{cite web|url=http://www.dilloneustace.com/download/1/Publications/Tax/Holding%20Companies%20in%20Ireland.pdf|title=Holding Companies in Ireland|publisher=Dillon Eustace Law Partners (Dublin)|date=2016}} * [[Double Irish]] residency. Before 2015, Irish CT was based where a company was "managed and controlled" versus registered; the "[[Double Irish]]" ends in 2020. * [[Double Irish arrangement#Single malt|Single Malt]] residency. Post closure of the Double Irish to new entrants in 2015, it can be recreated by wordings in selective tax treaties (e.g. Malta and UAE). * Extensive treaties. {{As of| March 2018}}, Ireland has bilateral tax treaties with 73 countries (the 74th, Ghana, is pending).{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tax-agreements/double-taxation-treaties/index.aspx?page=u|title=Double Irish Taxation Treaties|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=March 2018}} * Holding company regime. Built for [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]], it gives Irish–based holding companies tax relief on withholding taxes, foreign dividends and CGT.{{cite web|url=http://www.btconsulting.ie/page17/files/UK%20PLC%20Inversion.pdf|title=Inversion of UK plcs to Ireland|publisher=BT Consulting|date=2009|quote= However, in recent times, it is Ireland’s treatment of profits made by foreign subsidiaries of Irish resident companies that has been attracting attention and encouraging, in particular, UK firms to move their holding companies to Ireland and become tax resident there in order to reduce their tax burden.}} * [[Intellectual property]] regime. Built for the BEPS tools of U.S. technology and life sciences firms, recognises a wide range of [[Intellectual capital|intellectual assets]] that can be charged against Irish tax; the [[CAIA arrangement]]. * Knowledge Development Box. Ireland created the first OECD–compliant KDB in 2016 to support its IP–based BEPS tools. ===Yearly returns (2001–2017)=== [[File:Irish Corporation Tax as % of Total Tax (1989 to 2012).jpg|thumb|Irish Corporation Tax as a % Irish Exchequer Tax has between between 10% to 16% of Total Irish Tax. Source: [[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]{{cite web|url=https://taxpolicy.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/CT-Strategy-Presentation-for-Website-FINAL.pdf | title=Ireland’s Corporation Tax Strategy | author=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]] | date=1 April 2013}}]] [[File:Irish Corporation Tax (% of GDP and % of Total Tax).png|thumb|Irish Corporation Tax as % of Irish GDP, and as % of Total Irish Gross{{efn|name="gross"}} Tax (1974 to 2016). Source: OECD.]] The trends in Irish corporation tax ("CT") receipts to the Irish Exchequer were:{{cite web|url=http://www.fiscalcouncil.ie/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/AN-10-Challenges-Forecasting-Irish-Corporation-Tax-Final-Web.pdf|title=Irish Corporate Tax Forecasting Analytical Note 10| publisher=[[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/corporate/documents/research/ct-analysis-2018.pdf|title=Corporation Tax: 2017 Payments and 2016 Returns|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.audit.gov.ie/en/Find-Report/Publications/Report%20on%20the%20Accounts%20of%20the%20Public%20Services/Report%20on%20the%20Accounts%20of%20the%20Public%20Services%202016.html|title=Report on the Accounts of the Public Services 2016 (Chapter 20: Corporation Tax Receipts)|publisher=[[Comptroller and Auditor General of Ireland]] |date=April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.finance.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/180103-End-December-2017-Exchequer-Returns-Presentation.pdf|title=End December 2017 Exchequer Returns Presentation|publisher=Department of Finance|date=3 January 2018}} * Foreign firms pay 80% of Irish ''CT Revenue'' (notwithstanding that large U.S.–controlled [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]] to Ireland, are classed as ''Irish'' firms).{{cite web|url=https://fora.ie/multinational-tax-ireland-2767900-May2016/|title=Most of Ireland's huge corporate tax haul last year came from foreign firms|publisher=[[Sunday Business Post]] FORA|date=14 May 2016}} * Irish ''CT Revenues'' jump in 2015, the year of Apple's [[leprechaun economics]] re-structure of its BEPS tools. * Since Apple's 2015 re-structure, Irish ''CT Revenue'' as a % of ''Total Irish Exchequer Tax Revenue'' is at its pre-crisis peak of over 16% (OECD average is 7.5%); * Irish ''CT Revenue'' has been 10 to 16% of ''Total Irish Exchequer Tax Revenue'' (see graphic). * The concentration of the ''Top 10 Irish CT Payers'' has risen post the crisis, despite the fact that Irish banks stopped paying Irish CT due to accumulated losses.{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/corporate/documents/research/corporation-tax.pdf|title=Corporation Tax – A Note on the Context and Concentration of Payments|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=October 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0621/884543-corporation/|title=20 multinationals paid half of all Corporation tax paid in 2016|publisher=RTE News|date=21 June 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" |Table 3: Irish Corporation Tax (CT) Revenues: 2001–2007 (€ billion) |- !style="width:120px;text-align:left"|Calendar
