[[File:Impact of Ireland Corporation Tax Regime on Ireland's Economy.jpg|thumb|Effect of Ireland's Corporate Tax system on Ireland's relative GNI-per-capita to the EU average{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2015/11/11/how-ireland-became-an-offshore-financial-centre/|title=How Ireland became a tax haven and offshore financial centre|publisher=[[Nicholas Shaxson]], [[Tax Justice Network]]|date=11 November 2015|quote=The simple popular story is that Ireland used its 12.5 percent low corporate tax rate, and tax loopholes, to attract foreign multinational corporations, and built the so-called “Celtic Tiger” Irish economic boom on the back of that, helping Ireland become the single largest location outside the US for the declared pre-tax profits of U.S. firms.}}]] Ireland's economic model was transformed from a predominantly agricultural-based economy to a knowledge-based economy, when the EU agreed to waive EU State-aid rules to allow Ireland's '''special rate''' of 10% for manufacturing (created in 1980–81 with the EU's agreement), to be extended to the [[special economic zone]] called the [[International Financial Services Centre]] ("IFSC") in Dublin city centre in 1987. The transformation was accelerated when Ireland's standard corporate tax rate was reduced from 40% to 12.5% (phased in from 1996–2003), in response to the EU's 1996–1998 decision to withdraw the State-aid waiver. The passing of the ''1997 Taxes and Consolidated Acts'' laid the legal foundations for the [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tools used by U.S. multinationals in Ireland (e.g. the [[Double Irish]], the [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]] and the [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPV]]), to achieve an effective Irish CT rate, or ''[[#ETR|ETR]]'', of 0–3%.{{efn|name="ETR"}} While low CT rates (and evern lower [[#ETR|effective tax rates]]), are a central part of Irish tax policy, non–CT ''[[Taxation in the Republic of Ireland]]'' is closer to EU–28 and OECD averages.{{efn|However, only when Irish [[Modified gross national income]] (or GNI*) is used for comparision, rather than Irish GDP which is artificially inflated and distorted by BEPS flows. See [[#Distortion of GDP]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.finance.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/131017-BOC-DEW-Slides.pdf|title=The structure of Ireland’s tax system and options for growth enhancing reform|author=Brendan O'Connor|publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]}}{{cite journal|url=https://www.esr.ie/article/view/93|title=The Structure of Ireland’s Tax System and Options for Growth Enhancing Reform|author=Brendan O'Connor|publisher=The Economic and Social Review Quarterly|volume=44|issue=4|date=August 2013}} Ireland's policy is summarised by the OECD's ''Hierarchy of Taxes'' pyramid (reproduced in the [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]] Tax Strategy Group's 2011 corporate tax policy document).{{Cite web|title=Tax Strategy Group: Irish Corporate Taxation|page=3|url=http://taxpolicy.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/11.19-Corporation-Tax.pdf|date=October 2011|publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]}} As shown in {{slink|#Yearly returns (2001–2017)}}, annual Irish CT has been between 10 and 16 percent of annual Total Irish Tax from circa 1994 to 2018. From 2000–2014, Ireland's Total Tax-to-GDP ratio was circa 27–30%, versus the OECD average of 33%.{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/tax/revenue-statistics-ireland.pdf|title=Revenue Statistics 2017 - Ireland|publisher=[[OECD]]|date=2017}} However, since Apple's [[leprechaun economics]] Irish restructuring artificially inflated Ireland's GDP by 34.3% in 2015, Ireland's Tax-to-GDP ratio had fallen to the bottom of the OECD range at under 23%. [[File:OECD Hierarchy of Taxes.png|thumb|Recreation of the OECD "Hierarchy of Taxes" used by Ireland.]] In June 2018, international tax academics confirmed that Ireland was the largest global [[tax haven]], exceeding the combined flows of the entire Caribbean tax haven system. As international tax academics have shown, being a leading corporate tax haven has been a prosperous economy strategy for Ireland.{{cite journal|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/39181/921.pdf?sequence=1|title=Do Tax Havens Flourish|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|journal=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], ''Tax Policy and the Economy''|quote=ABSTRACT: Per capita real GDP in tax haven countries grew at an average annual rate of 3.3 percent between 1982 and 1999, which compares favorably to the world average of 1.4 percent.|volume=19|page=65-99|date=2005}} However, as the tax academics also predicted, the artificial distortion of Ireland's economic data, and GDP in particular, by BEPS flows, led to a large credit bubble during 2003–2007 (due to the mispricing of Ireland's credit), and an eventual credit–property–banking crisis in 2008–2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/p_imk_wp_175_2017.pdf|author=Heike Joebges|title=CRISIS RECOVERY IN A COUNTRY WITH A HIGH PRESENCE OF FOREIGN-OWNED COMPANIES: The Case of Ireland |publisher=IMK Macroeconomic Policy Institute, [[Hans-Böckler-Stiftung]]|date=January 2017}} Ireland's main foreign multinationals are from periods when their home jurisdiction had a "worldwide tax" system (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''), and since the UK switched to a "territorial tax" system in 2009–12, Ireland has been almost exclusively a U.S. corporate–[[tax haven]] (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). In October 2014, the ''[[The Guardian]]'' quoted the Irish lead singer of ''[[U2]]'', ''[[Bono]]'' as saying that "his country’s tax policies have "brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known"".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/bono-tax-laws-bring-ireland-prosperity-apple-google-u2|title=Bono: controversial tax laws have brought Ireland the only prosperity it’s ever known|date=12 October 2014|author=Rupert Neate|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|quote=In an interview with the Observer, the Irish singer says his country’s tax policies have “brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known”. Bono said: “We are a tiny little country, we don’t have scale, and our version of scale is to be innovative and to be clever, and tax competitiveness has brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known. “That’s how we got these companies here … We don’t have natural resources, we have to be able to attract people.”}} In April 2016, award-winning Irish writer, [[Fintan O'Toole]] labeled Ireland's focus on being a U.S. corporate tax haven as the core economic model, as Ireland's OBI, (or "One Big Idea").{{cite web| url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/fintan-o-toole-us-taxpayers-growing-tired-of-ireland-s-one-big-idea-1.2615065|title=US taxpayers growing tired of Ireland’s one big idea|author=[[Fintan O'Toole]]|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=16 April 2016|quote=The losses to the US budget from corporate tax avoidance are now out of control. The US loses as much as $111 billion each year due to corporate tax dodging – and let’s be honest, Ireland is implicated in a significant amount of this. [...] This is arguably the biggest economic challenge facing Ireland over the next decade}} ===Multinational economy=== [[File:EUROSTAT Ireland Gross Operating Surplus by Controlling Country, €million 2015.png|thumb|upright=1.0|Dominance of U.S. firms. Irish corporate ''Gross Operating Surplus'' (i.e. profits), by the controlling country of the company (note: a material part of the Irish figure is also from U.S. [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversion]]s who are U.S.–controlled). Eurostat (2015).{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.com/2018/06/who-shifts-profits-to-ireland.html|title=Who shifts profits to Ireland|publisher=Economic Incentives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=18 June 2018|quote=Eurostat’s structural business statistics give a range of measures of the business economy broken down by the controlling country of the enterprises. Here is the Gross Operating Surplus generated in Ireland in 2015 for the countries with figures reported by Eurostat.}}]] U.S.–controlled multinationals, either legally based in the U.S. or legally based in Ireland (e.g. tax inversions), dominate Ireland's economy. In June 2018, the ''American Chamber of Commerce (Ireland)'' estimated the value of U.S. investment in Ireland was €334 billion, which compared to 2017 Irish [[GNI*]] [[Modified gross national income#Irish GDP versus Modified GNI (2009–2017)|of €181.2 billion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/denouncing-ireland-as-a-tax-haven-is-as-dated-as-calling-it-homophobic-because-of-our-past-37032219.html|title=Denouncing Ireland as a tax haven is as dated as calling it homophobic because of our past|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 June 2018|quote=The total value of US business investment in Ireland - ranging from data centres to the world's most advanced manufacturing facilities - stands at $387bn (€334bn) - this is more than the combined US investment in South America, Africa and the Middle East, and more than the BRIC countries combined.}} In January 2018, [[Eurostat]] used 2015 data to show the ''gross operating surplus'' of foreign companies in Ireland was almost exclusively from U.S. companies, with the UK was a distant second, and little other foreign firm activity (see graphic). Not only did U.S. companies rank ahead of Irish companies, but a material quantum of the ''gross operating surplus'' attributed to Irish companies, is from U.S. tax inversion such as [[Medtronic]], [[Eaton Corporation|Eaton]] and [[Allergan]], who are in effect, U.S.–controlled multinationals, and have little attachment to Ireland. In 2016–2017, foreign multinationals, being entirely U.S.–controlled: * Directly employed one–quarter of the Irish private sector workforce;{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/investment/IRELAND-trade-investment-statistical-country-note.pdf|title=IRELAND Trade and Statistical Note 2017|publisher=OECD|date=2017|pages=2-5}} * Paid an average wage of €85k (€17.9bn wage roll on 210,443 staff) versus the Irish Industrial wage of €35k;{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/docs/publications/ida_strategy_final|title=Winning FDI 2015–2019 Strategy|publisher=IDA Ireland|date=March 2015}} * Directly contributed €28.3 billion annually in taxes, wages and capital spending; * Paid 80% of all Irish corporation and Irish business taxes; * Paid 50% of all Irish salary taxes (due to higher paying jobs), 50% of all Irish VAT, and 92% of all Irish customs and excise duties;{{efn|These figures were stated by Suzanne Kelly, a leading Irish tax expert and tax barrister, and the Past President of the Irish Tax Institute; but they are not fully verifiable from public sources.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/multinationals-tax-contribution-ireland-facts-2972139-Sep2016/|title=FactCheck: How much do multinationals actually contribute in taxes?|publisher=thejournal.ie|date=9 September 2016}}}} * Created 57% of private sector non–farm value–add: 40% of value–add in Irish services and 80% of value–add in Irish manufacturing); * Made up 25 of the top 50 Irish companies (by 2017 turnover) (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). ===Multinational features=== The main features regarding foreign multinationals in Ireland are: * '''They are almost exclusively U.S.''' U.S.–controlled multinationals are 25 of the top 50 firms in Ireland, and 70% of top 50 firm revenue (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). This includes U.S. multinationals that are legally headquartered in Ireland (e.g. [[Medtronic]]), but who are run from the U.S. (e.g. all senior executives and the main offices are in the U.S.).{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/article.php?id=2116085|title=Most of Ireland’s biggest companies aren’t Irish at all | publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|date=22 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.top1000.ie/companies|title=2017: Ireland's Top 1,000 Companies | publisher=[[Irish Times]]| date=2018}} * '''The are from countries with "worldwide tax" systems'''. Tax academics show that firms from "territorial tax" systems (over 95% of all countries),{{efn|name="territorial"|"Territorial tax" systems have the flexibility to apply much lower tax rates on foreign sourced income to incentivise companies to maintain their headquarters at home (e.g. Germany applies a 5% tax on foreign profits).{{Cite web|title = A Territorial Tax System Would Create Jobs and Raise Wages for U.S. Workers|url = https://www.heritage.org/taxes/report/territorial-tax-system-would-create-jobs-and-raise-wages-us-workers|publisher = The Heritage Foundation|date = 12 September 2013}} Prior to the 2017 U.S. ''[[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]]'', the U.S. was one of 7 remaining jurisdictions (e.g. Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico and the U.S.), to operate a "worldwide tax" system which applied a fixed single high rate of 35% tax on all worldwide income.{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2013/wp13205.pdf|title=Territorial vs. Worldwide Corporate Taxation: Implications for Developing Countries|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=2013|page=4}}}} make little use of [[tax havens]].{{cite journal| url = https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2831&context=articles|title=Multinational Firms and Tax Havens|author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Anna Gumpert|author3=Monika Schnitzer|date=2016|journal=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]]|page=714|quote=Germany taxes only 5% of the active foreign business profits of its resident corporations. [..] Furthermore, German firms do not have incentives to structure their foreign operations in ways that avoid repatriating income. Therefore, the tax incentives for German firms to establish tax haven affiliates are likely to differ from those of U.S. firms and bear strong similarities to those of other G–7 and OECD firms.|volume=98|issue=4}} The only non–U.S. foreign firms in the top 50 Irish firms are UK firms from pre–2009, after which the UK switched to a "territorial tax" system.{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/tax-reform-uk-reversed-tide-corporate-tax-inversions/|title=How Tax Reform solved UK inversions|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|author=William McBride|date=14 October 2014}}{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/united-kingdom-s-experience-inversions/|title=The United Kingdom's Experience with Inversions|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]||author=Kyle Pomerleau|date=5 April 2016}} In December 2017, the U.S. switched to a hybrid-"territorial tax" system.{{efn|name="hybrid"}} * '''They are concentrated.''' The top–20 corporate taxpayers pay 50% of all Irish corporate taxes, while the top–10 pay 40% of all Irish corporate taxes. Post–[[leprechaun economics]], Apple, Ireland's largest company by turnover (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''), constitutes over one–quarter of Ireland's GDP.{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2018/0417/955163-iphone-effect-on-irish-economy/|title=Quarter of Irish economic growth due to Apple's iPhone, says IMF|publisher=RTE News|date=17 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/iphone-exports-accounted-for-quarter-of-irish-economic-growth-in-2017-imf-1.3464658|title=iPhone exports accounted for quarter of Irish economic growth in 2017 - IMF|publisher=Irish Times|date=17 April 2018}} The top 10 U.S.–controlled multinationals comfortably account for over 50% of Irish 2017 GDP.{{efn|Apple's Q1 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] re-structure increased Irish GDP by up to 34.4% (e.g. Apple is at least one-quarter of Irish GDP). The next 9 largest U.S.–controlled multinationals have a combined 2017 Irish turnover of €144.0 billion that exceeds Apple's 2017 Irish turnover of €119.2 billion (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]'')}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c69ed976-fbab-11e7-9b32-d7d59aace167|title=Ireland enjoys tax boom but fears a reckoning|publisher=Financial Times|date=31 January 2018}} * '''They are mostly technology and life sciences.''' To use Ireland's main BEPS tools, a multinational needs to have [[intellectual property]] (or "IP"), which is then converted into [[intellectual capital]] and [[royalty payment]] plans, which ''shift profits'' from high–tax locations to Ireland. Most global IP is concentrated in the technology and life sciences industries (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]'').{{cite web|url=https://chicagounbound.uchicago.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2385&context=law_and_economics|title=What Do We Know About Base Erosion and Profit Shifting? A Review of the Empirical Literature|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|year=2014|quote= It focuses particularly on the dominant approach within the economics literature on income shifting, which dates back to Hines and Rice (1994) and which we refer to as the “Hines–Rice” approach.|page=1}}{{cite book | url= http://www.wipo.int/edocs/pubdocs/en/wipo_pub_943_2017.pdf | title=WIPO IP Facts and Figures 2017 | date=April 2018 | isbn=9789280529142 | publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]]}} * '''They use Ireland to shield all non–U.S. profits, not just EU profits, from the US "worldwide tax" system.''' In 2016, Facebook recorded global revenues of $27 billion, while Facebook (Ireland) paid €30 million in Irish tax on Irish revenues of €13 billion (half of all global revenues).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/technology/facebook-paid-just-30m-tax-in-ireland-despite-earning-12bn-36362527.html|title=Facebook paid just €30m tax in Ireland despite earning €12bn|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Adrian Weckler|date=29 November 2017}}{{efn|Similarly, when the EU introduced the [[GDPR]] regulations in 2018, Facebook disclosed that all of its non–U.S. accounts (circa 1.9 billion, of which 1.5 billion were non-E.U), were legally based in Dublin.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-privacy-eu-exclusive/exclusive-facebook-to-put-1-5-billion-users-out-of-reach-of-new-eu-privacy-law-idUSKBN1HQ00P|title=Exclusive: Facebook to put 1.5 billion users out of reach of new EU privacy law|publisher=[[Reuters]]|author=David Ingram|date=18 April 2018}}}} Similarly, Google also runs most of its non–U.S. revenue and profits through its Dublin operation.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/nov/04/google-pays-47m-euros-tax-ireland-22bn-euros-revenue|title=Google pays €47m in tax in Ireland on €22bn sales revenue|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|author=Simon Bowers|date=4 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1026612.shtml|title=Google booked 41% of global revenues in Ireland in 2012; A leprechaun's gold?|publisher=Finfacts.ie|date=30 September 2013}} * '''They artificially inflate Irish GDP by 62%.''' All [[tax havens]] have a [[Tax haven#Inflated GDP-per-capita|distorted GDP]] due to the effect of BEPS flows. Apple's Q1 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] re-structuring of their Double Irish BEPS tool into a CAIA BEPS tool, increased the distortion to such a level that in February 2017, the [[Central Bank of Ireland|Central Bank]] replaced Irish GDP with [[Modified gross national income|GNI*]]. In 2017, Irish GDP was [[Modified gross national income#Irish GDP versus Modified GNI (2009–2017)|162%]] of 2017 GNI*.{{efn|name="gnigdp"}} * '''They pay effective tax rates of 0–3%.''' Irish [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]] quote an effective 2015 CT rate of 9.8%, but this omits profits deemed not taxable.{{cite web|url=https://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/Archive2013/Country%20Reports/Ireland.pdf|title=TAX JUSTICE NETWORK: Ireland Financial Secrecy Index Country Report 2014|quote=Misleadingly, studies cited by the Irish Times and other outlets suggest that the effective tax rate is close to the headline 12.5 percent rate – but this is a fictional result based on a theoretical ‘standard firm with 60 employees’ and no exports: it is entirely inapplicable to transnationals. Though there are various ways to calculate effective tax rates, other studies find rates of just 2.5-4.5 percent.|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=November 2014}} The US [[Bureau of Economic Analysis]] gives an effective 2015 Irish CT rate of 2.5%. BEA agrees with the Irish CT rates of Apple, Google and Facebook (<1%),{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/technology/facebook-paid-just-30m-tax-in-ireland-despite-earning-12bn-36362527.html|title=Facebook paid just €30m tax in Ireland despite earning €12bn|publisher=Irish Indepdenent|date=29 November 2017}} and the CT rates of Irish BEPS tools (0-3%).{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/almost-half-of-irish-registered-firms-profits-cannot-be-taxed-1.1836061|title=Almost half of Irish-registered firms’ profits ‘cannot be taxed’|publisher=Irish Times|date=18 June 2014}} ({{slink|#Effective tax rate (ETR)}}) ===Multinational job focus=== {{see also|Corporate haven#Employment tax}} Ireland's corporate BEPS tools emphasise job creation (either of Irish employees or of foreign employees to Ireland). To use Irish BEPS tools, and their [[#ETR|ETR]]s of 0–3%,{{efn|name="ETR"}} the multinational must meet conditions on the [[intellectual property]] ("IP") they will be using as part of their Irish BEPS tool. This is outlined in the Irish Finance Acts particular to each scheme, but in summary, the multinational must:{{Cite web|title=Intangible Assets Scheme under Section 291A Taxes Consolidation Act 1997 |url = https://www.revenue.ie/ga/tax-professionals/historic-material/tax-briefing/2010/tax-briefing-issue-09-2010.pdf|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=2010}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-09/09-02-05.pdf|title=Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets under section 291A of the Taxes Consolidation Act 1997 (Part 9 / Chapter2)|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=February 2018}} * Prove they are carrying out a "relevant trade" on the IP in Ireland (i.e. Ireland is not just an "empty shell" through which IP passes en route to another tax haven); * Prove the level of Irish employment doing the "relevant activities" on the IP is consistent with the Irish tax relief being claimed (the ratio has never been disclosed);{{efn|There are fewer cases of U.S. technology multinationals conducting genuine software programming origination in Ireland. The "high-value" Irish jobs tend to be "[[language localisation]]" work (e.g. converting software into different languages) or "sales and marketing". These are sufficient to meet the Irish [[Revenue Commissioners]] criteria for a "relevant trade" and "relevant activities".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/work/ireland-s-top-tech-companies-who-pays-the-most-1.2526778|title=Google UK employees paid double their Irish equivalent|publisher=Irish Times|date=February 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/may/29/apple-tax-profits-ireland-cork|title=Apple's multi-billion dollar, low-tax profit hub: Knocknaheeny, Ireland|publisher=The Guardian|date=29 May 2013}}}} * Show that the average wages of the Irish employees are consistent with such a "relevant trade" (i.e. must be "high-value" jobs earning +€60,000–€90,000 per annum);{{efn|In March 2018, [[IDA Ireland]] disclosed that foreign multinationals paid €17.9 billion in wage on 210,443 Irish staff, or €85k per employee ("high-value" jobs) in 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/newsroom/publications/ireland-s-economic-and-competitiveness-update-q1|title=IDA Ireland Competitiveness|publisher=IDA Ireland|date=March 2018}}}} * Put this into an approved "business plan" (agreed with Revenue Commissioners and other State bodies, such as IDA Ireland), for the term of the tax relief scheme; * Agree to suffer "clawbacks" of the Irish tax relief granted (i.e. pay the full 12.5% level), if they leave before the end plan (5 years for schemes started after February 2013) The percentage of Irish wage-to-profits has never been disclosed, however, commentators imply the Irish wage-roll needs to be circa 2–3% of gross Irish profits: * Apple employed 6,000 people in 2014, and at say €100,000 cost per employee gives a €600 million wage-roll on 2014 Irish profits of €25 billion (see table below),{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/revealed-eight-facts-you-may-not-know-about-the-apple-irish-plant-36409796.html|title=Revealed Eight facts you may not know about the Apple Irish plant|publisher=Irish Independent|date=15 December 2017}} or 2.4% * Google employed 2,763 people in 2014, and at say €100,000 cost per employee gives a €276 million wage roll on Google 2014 Irish profits of €12 billion,{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/Irish_finance_news/articleDetail.php?Does-Google-Ireland-have-6-000-employees-in-Ireland-649|title=Does Google Ireland have 6,000 employees in Ireland?|publisher=FinFacts|date=2015}} or 2.3% To the extent that the Irish jobs are performing real functions (e.g. the function is not replicated elsewhere in the Group), the cost is not a "employment tax", however, at worst case, the U.S. multinational should incur an aggregate effective Irish corporation tax of 2–6% (actual Irish BEPS tool tax of 0–3%,{{efn|name="ETR"}} plus Irish employment costs of 2–3%). Therefore, as shown in {{slink|#Yearly returns (2001–2017)}}, while Irish CT has consistently been between 10 and 15% of Total Irish Tax, the additional employment contribution made by U.S. multinationals in Ireland, has led to strong growth in overall Irish Total Taxes. ===Top 50 Irish Corporates=== {{anchor|Table 1}} The top 50 Irish companies, ranked by 2017 Irish registered revenues, are as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |+ style="text-align: left;" |Table 1: Top 50 Irish companies by 2017 revenue booked in Ireland (€ billions) |- !style="width:95px;text-align:left"|Rank

2017 revenue (or 26%); | There are no other firms in the top 50 Irish companies from other jurisdictions. }} ==Multinational tax schemes== {{Main article|Double Irish arrangement}} ===Background=== [[File:Ireland Trade Good Discrepancy (1995-2017).png|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' The Q1 2015 restructuring of Apple's non–U.S. IP to Ireland ([[leprechaun economics]]), is the largest [[BEPS]] action in history.
[[Brad Setser]] & Cole Frank ([[Council on Foreign Relations|CoFR]]).]] The tax schemes used by U.S. multinationals in Ireland are called [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tools by tax academics. Whereas Ireland's ''headline'' corporation tax rate is 12.5%, Ireland's BEPS tools enable an [[#ETR|effective tax rate]] of 0% to 3% to be achieved, depending on which BEPS tool is used.{{efn|name="ETR"}} Ireland has been associated with U.S. multinational ''profit shifting'' to avoid taxes since the U.S. IRS produced a list on the 12 January 1981.{{efn|name="gordon1"|Ireland was listed as a ''manufacturing tax haven'' in the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS) (1981) Tax Haven and Their Use by United States Taxpayers (The Gordon Report). Washington, D.C.: Special Council for International Taxation, Internal Revenue Service}}{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/taxhavenstheirus01gord|title=Tax Havens and their use by United States Taxpayers, An Overview|publisher=U.S. Internal Revenue Service|date=12 January 1981}} In February 1994, the U.S. tax academic, [[James R. Hines Jr.]] identified Ireland as one of seven "major" tax havens for U.S. multinational ''profit shifting''.{{cite journal|url=http://taxdoctoralseminar.web.unc.edu/files/2016/02/Hines-Rice.pdf|title=FISCAL PARADISE: FOREIGN TAX HAVENS AND AMERICAN BUSINESS |author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Eric M. Rice|quote=We identify 41 countries and regions as tax havens for the purposes of U. S. businesses. Together the seven tax havens with populations greater than one million (Hong Kong, Ireland, Liberia, Lebanon, Panama, Singapore, and Switzerland) account for 80 percent of total tax haven population and 89 percent of tax haven GDP. |journal=[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] (Harvard/MIT)|date=February 1994|volume=9|issue=1}} During the 2014–2016 [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland|EU investigation into Apple's Irish BEPS tools]], it was revealed that the Irish [[Revenue Commissioners]] had been issuing private rulings on Apple's [[Double Irish]] BEPS tools as far back as 1991; and that Apple, Ireland's largest company, had an ETR of less than 1%. In 2014, the EU Commission forced Ireland to close its Double Irish BEPS tool, however, Ireland had replacements in place: the ''[[Single malt arrangement|Single Malt]]'' (2014), and the ''[[CAIA arrangement|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]'' (CAIA) (2009). When Apple closed its hybrid–Double Irish BEPS tool in Q1 2015 and restructured into the CAIA BEPS tool, the Irish [[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)|Central Statistics Office]] ("CSO") had to re-state Irish 2015 GDP as Apple's CAIA tool had artificially inflated Irish GDP by 34.4%; an event [[Paul Krugman]] christened in July 2016 as [[Leprechaun economics]]. Because the Irish CSO delayed the re-statement and redacted normal economic data to protect Apple's identity,{{cite web|url=http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/newsevents/documents/pr_GDPexplanatorynote.pdf|title=CSO Press Release|publisher=[[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)]]|quote=As a consequence of the overall scale of these additions, elements of the results that would previously been published are now suppressed to protect the confidentiality of the contributing companies, in accordance with the Statistics Act 1993|date=12 July 2016}} it was not until January 2018, that economists could confirm Apple as the source of "leprechaun economics",{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.ie/2018/01/what-apple-did-next.html|title=What Apple did next|publisher=Economic Perspectives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=24 January 2018}} and that at $300 billion, was the largest BEPS action in history. By February 2017, the distortion of Irish economic data by Irish BEPS tools had grown so large, that the [[Central Bank of Ireland]] replaced GDP with [[Modified gross national income|Modified GNI]]; 2017 Irish GNI* is 40% below Irish GDP (see ''[[#Table 2|Table 2]]''}. {{quote box |width=18.5em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote = Of the wider tax environment, O’Rourke thinks the OECD base-erosion and profit-shifting (BEPS) process is "very good" for Ireland. "If BEPS sees itself to a conclusion, it will be good for Ireland." |salign=left|source=[[Feargal O'Rourke]] (2015)
CEO PwC (Ireland)
''Architect'' of the [[Double Irish]]}} In November 2016, Ireland signed the [[Base erosion and profit shifting#OECD BEPS Project|OECD BEPS Multilateral Instrument]] ("MLI") to curb global BEPS tools but opted out of Article 12 to protect the Single Malt and CAIA BEPS tools.{{Cite web|author=Jack Power|title = Ireland resists closing corporation tax ‘loophole’|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/ireland-resists-closing-corporation-tax-loophole-1.3286199|work=The Irish Times|date=10 November 2017|quote=Global legal firm [[Baker McKenzie]], representing a coalition of 24 multinational US software firms, including Microsoft, lobbied [[Michael Noonan (Fine Gael politician)|Michael Noonan]], as [Irish] minister for finance, to resist the [OECD MLI] proposals in January 2017. In a letter to him the group recommended Ireland not adopt article 12, as the changes “will have effects lasting decades” and could “hamper global investment and growth due to uncertainty around taxation”. The letter said that “keeping the current standard will make Ireland a more attractive location for a regional headquarters by reducing the level of uncertainty in the tax relationship with Ireland’s trading partners”}} In March 2018, the [[Financial Stability Forum]] showed Ireland's Debt–based BEPS tools made it the 3rd–largest [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]] in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/P050318-1.pdf|title=Global Shadow Banking and Monitoring Report: 2017|date=5 March 2018|quote=Jurisdictions with the largest financial systems relative to GDP (Exhibit 2-3) tend to have relatively larger OFI [or Shadown Banking] sectors: Luxembourg (at 92% of total financial assets), the Cayman Islands (85%), Ireland (76%) and the Netherlands (58%)|page=30|publisher=[[Financial Stability Forum]]}} In June 2018, tax academics showed Irish IP–based BEPS tools were artificially distorting ''aggregate'' EU GDP data,{{cite web|url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/ireland-exports-its-leprechaun|quote=Ireland has, more or less, stopped using GDP to measure its own economy. And on current trends [because Irish GDP is distorting EU–28 aggregate data], the eurozone taken as a whole may need to consider something similar.|title=Ireland Exports its Leprechaun|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|date=11 May 2018}} and had artificially inflated the EU–U.S. trade-deficit.{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2018.pdf|title=The Missing Profits of Nations∗|quote=Profit shifting also has a significant effect on trade balances. For instance, after accounting for profit shifting, Japan, the UK, France, and Greece turn out to have trade surpluses in 2015, in contrast to the published data that record trade deficits. According to our estimates, the true trade deficit of the United States was 2.1% of GDP in 2015, instead of 2.8% in the official statistics—that is, a quarter of the recorded trade deficit of the United States is an illusion of multinational corporate tax avoidance.|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Tørsløv|author3=Ludvig Wier|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|page=25|date=8 June 2018}} In June 2018, tax academics confirmed IP–based BEPS tools had made Ireland the world's largest tax haven, and that the $106 billion of annual corporate profits shielded by Irish BEPS tools, exceeded the BEPS flows of the entire Caribbean tax haven system. ===Key features=== ====Intellectual property==== {{see also|Corporate haven#IP–based BEPS tools}} [[File:GIPC Intellectual Property 2018 (Patents Sub-Category).png|thumb|2018 GIPC League Table: ''Patents'' Sub-Category.]] Ireland's main BEPS tools use [[intellectual property]] (IP) to effect the ''profit shift'' from the higher-tax locations to Ireland, via [[royalty payment]] schemes. To avoid incurring Irish corporation tax on these ''shifted profits'', the BEPS tools either send-on the profits to traditional tax havens (with explicit 0% CT rates) via royalty payment schemes (e.g. the Double Irish and Single Malt BEPS tools), or use intangible capital allowances schemes to write-off the profits against Irish tax (e.g. the CAIA BEPS tool).{{cite web|url=http://ftp.zew.de/pub/zew-docs/dp/dp13078.pdf|title=Profit Shifting and "Aggressive" Tax Planning by Multinational Firms|publisher=[[Zentrum für Europäische Wirtschaftsforschung|Centre for European Economic Research]], (ZEW)|author1=Clemens Fuest|author2=Christoph Spengel|author3=Katharina Finke|author4=Jost Heckemeyer|author5=Hannah Nusser|date=15 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://arno.uvt.nl/show.cgi?fid=143915| title=Intellectual Property Tax Planning in the light of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting | publisher=University of Tilburg | date=June 2017}} This is the reason why most U.S. multinationals in Ireland are from the two largest IP–industries, namely technology companies and life sciences; or, are specific companies with valuable industrial patents such as Ingersoll-Rand and Eaton Corporation.{{cite web | url=http://www.fordhamiplj.org/2016/08/30/ip-tax-avoidance-ireland/ | title=Intellectual Property and Tax Avoidance in Ireland | publisher=[[Fordham Intellectual Property, Media & Entertainment Law Journal]] | date=30 August 2016}} Ireland describes its IP–based BEPS tools as being part of its "knowledge economy"; however, U.S. tax academics describe IP as "the leading tax-avoidance vehicle in the world".{{cite web | url=https://www.uclalawreview.org/pdf/62-1-1.pdf | page=4|title=Intellectual Property Law Solutions to Tax Avoidance | publisher=UCLA Law Review | date=2015 | quote=Intellectual property (IP) has become the leading tax avoidance vehicle in the world today.}}{{cite web | url=https://www.bnrbeurs.nl/2017/02/22/the-corporate-tax-avoidance-toolbox/| title=The Corporate Tax Avoidance Toolbox|publisher=B&R Beurs|date=2018}} Despite its small size, Ireland ranks 6th in the 2018 U.S. [[Global Intellectual Property Center]] (GIPC) league table of the top 50 global centres for IP–leglislation, and 4th in the important ''Patents'' sub-category (see graphic opposite).{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalipcenter.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GIPC_IP_Index_2018.pdf|title=U.S. Chamber International IP Index, 6th Edition, 2018|publisher=[[Global Intellectual Property Center]]|date=February 2018|page=6}} While Ireland's most important BEPS tools are all IP–based, Ireland has other BEPS tools including Transfer Pricing–based BEPS tools (e.g. [[contract manufacturing]]), and Debt–based BEPS tools (e.g. the Irish [[Section 110 SPV]], and the Irish [[L-QIAIF]]). ===="Worldwide Tax" systems==== Ireland's IP–based BEPS tools have only attracted material operations from multinationals whose home jurisdiction had a "worldwide tax" system; namely, the U.K pre–2009, and the U.S. pre–2018 (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). Ireland has not attracted material technology or life sciences multinationals (outside of a specific plant, under its TP–based ''Contract Manufacturing'' BEPS tool), whose home jurisdiction operates a "territorial tax" system. {{As of|November 2018}}, there are only 6 remaining jurisdictions in the world who operate a "worldwide tax" system, of which Ireland is one (e.g. Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico).{{efn|name="territorial"}} In 2016, U.S. tax academic, [[James R. Hines Jr.]] showed firms from "territorial tax" systems make little use of corporate–[[tax havens]], as their tax code applied lower rates to foreign-sourced profits. Hines, with German tax academics, showed the German tax code charged a CT rate of 5% to the foreign profits of German multinationals. Hines was one of the most-cited sources when the U.S. [[Council of Economic Advisors]] advocated switching the U.S. tax code to a "territorial system" in the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]].{{cite web| url= https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/documents/Tax%20Reform%20and%20Wages.pdf|publisher=[[Council of Economic Advisors]]|title=TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT OF 2017 Corporate Tax Reform and Wages: Theory and Evidence|quote=[In the Whitehouse advocating for the TCJA] Applying [[James R. Hines Jr.|Hines and Rice’s (1994)]] findings to a statutory corporate rate reduction of 15 percentage points (from 35 to 20 percent) suggests that reduced profit shifting would result in more than $140 billion of repatriated profit based on 2016 numbers.|date=17 October 2017}} In 2014, the U.S [[Tax Foundation]], reported on how the UK had effectively stopped UK corporates [[#UK inversions|inverting to Ireland]], by switching the UK corporate tax-code to a "territorial system" over 2009-2012. By 2014, the UK ''[[HM Revenue and Customs|HMRC]]'' reported that most of the UK multinationals that had inverted to Ireland had either returned to the UK (e.g., [[WPP plc]], [[United Busines Media plc]], [[Henderson Group plc]]), or were about to be acquired by U.S. multinationals as part of a U.S. corporate tax inversion to Ireland (e.g. [[Shire plc]]).{{efn|name="shire"|Shire's proposed 2014 corporate tax inversion with U.S. pharmaceutical [[AbbVie Inc.]] failed due to the 2016 Obama Administration anti-inversion rules.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/may/08/adderall-shire-takeover-takeda-virgin-money|title=Adderall maker Shire agrees to £46bn takeover by Takeda|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 March 2018|author=Julia Kollewe}} In 2018, Shire agreed to a lower $64 billion bid from Japanese pharmaceutical [[Takeda Pharmaceutical Company|Takeda]], who confirmed they would not be executing a tax inversion to Ireland (Japan's ''headline'' corporate tax rate is 35%), which was attributed to the fact that Japan, like the UK, switched to a "territorial tax" system in 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-shire-m-a-takeda-pharma-deal-exclusiv/shire-willing-to-back-64-billion-takeda-bid-market-signals-doubts-idUSKBN1HV2P4|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=26 April 2018|title=Shire willing to back $64 billion Takeda bid, market signals doubts|author=Ben Martin}}}} ====Distortion of GDP==== {{Main|Modified gross national income|Leprechaun economics}} {{quote box |width=18.5em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote = At this point, multinational profit shifting doesn't just distort Ireland’s balance of payments; it constitutes Ireland’s balance of payments. |salign=left |source=[[Brad Setser]], [[Council on Foreign Relations]], ''Tax Avoidance and the Irish Balance of Payments'' (2018){{cite web|url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/tax-avoidance-and-irish-balance-payments|title=Tax Avoidance and the Irish Balance of Payments|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|author1=[[Brad Setser]]|author2=Cole Frank|date=25 April 2018}}}} An "[[Tax haven#Inflated GDP-per-capita|artificially inflated GDP-per-capita statistic]]", is a known feature of tax havens, due to the BEPS flows. In February 2017, Ireland's national accounts became so distorted by BEPS flows that the [[Central Bank of Ireland]] replaced Irish GDP with a new economic measure, Irish [[Modified gross national income|Modified GNI*]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/dd3a6f1c-6aea-11e7-bfeb-33fe0c5b7eaa|title=Ireland's deglobalised data to calculate a smaller economy|publisher=Financial Times|date=17 July 2017}} However, in December 2017, [[Eurostat]] reported that Modified GNI* did not remove all of the distortions from Irish economic data.{{cite web|url= https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/cros/system/files/euronaissue2-2016-art2.pdf|title=Globalisation at work in statistics — Questions arising from the ‘Irish case’|publisher=[[EuroStat]]|author1=SILKE STAPEL-WEBER|author2=JOHN VERRINDER|quote=Nevertheless the rise in [Irish] GNI is still very substantial because the additional income flows of the companies (interest and dividends) concerned are considerably smaller than the value added of their activities|page=31| date=December 2017}} [[File:2011 Ratio of GNI to GDP (EuroStat National Accounts).png|thumb|'''EU 2011 Ratio of GNI to GDP''' (Eurostat Accounts, 2011).{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.ie/2013/04/gdp-and-international-comparisons.html|title=International GNI to GDP Comparisons|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|publisher=Economic Incentives|date=29 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/europe-points-finger-at-ireland-over-tax-avoidance-1.3417948|title=Europe points finger at Ireland over tax avoidance|publisher=Irish Times|date=7 March 2018|quote=Multinational companies have made such extensive use of Ireland to funnel royalties – a common way to shift profits and avoid tax – that these payments averaged 23 per cent of the country’s annual gross domestic product between 2010 and 2015, according to an EU Commission report seen by the ''Financial Times''.}}]] By September 2018, the Irish [[Central Statistics Office web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/nov/04/google-pays-47m-euros-tax-ireland-22bn-euros-revenue| title=Google pays €47m in tax in Ireland on €22bn sales revenue | publisher=The O'Rourke]], cousin of the 2008–2011 Irish Finance Minister [[Brian Lenihan Jnr]]) is regarded as its "grand architect".{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-10-28/man-making-ireland-tax-avoidance-hub-globally-proves-local-hero|author=Jesse Drucker|title=Man Making Ireland Tax Avoidance Hub Proves Local corporate profits from both Irish and U.S. taxation in 2015. As the BEPS tool with which U.S. multinationals built up untaxed offshore reserves of circa US$1 trillion from 2004 to 2017,{{efn|name="bush"|2004 was the date of the last Bush Administration tax amnesty, when pre–2004 offshore untaxed cash was repatriated at a special U.S. tax rate of 5%; in 2018, the TCJA repatriation tax rate was 15.5%.}}{{efn|name="bush2"|While various sources quote the amount of untaxed cash reserves as being closer to USD 2 trillion, a component of this figure represents cash flow that is awaiting reinvestment in the overseas markets, non-cash assets, and U.S. banking flows; the strong consensus is that the pure cash figure is at least over USD 1 trillion.{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/making-sense-profit-shifting-edward-kleinbard/|title=Making Sense of Profit Shifting: Edward Kleinbard|date=15 March 2015|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|author=Eric Cederwall|quote=We also know that the cash component of that is about $1 trillion. Therefore, we know from this that we're not talking simply about foreign investment in real foreign assets because somewhere in the neighborhood of $1 trillion is in cash and cash equivalents}}}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-real-story-behind-us-companies-off-shore-cash-reserves| title=The real story behind U.S. companies’ offshore cash reserves|publisher=[[McKinsey & Company]]|author1=David Cogman|author2=Tim Koller|quote=By our reckoning, the 500 largest U.S. nonfinancial companies have now accumulated around $1 trillion more than their businesses need. The majority of this is held offshore, in non-U.S. overseas subsidiaries, to avoid the incremental U.S. income taxes they would pay if they repatriated the money under current U.S. laws|date=June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/20/us-corporate-giants-hoarding-over-a-trillion-dollars-apple-microsoft-google| title=U.S. corporate giants hoarding more than a trillion dollars | publisher=[[The Guardian]] |author=Jill Treanor|quote=Earlier this year, anti-poverty charity Oxfam had estimated U.S. companies had $1.4tn in subsidiaries based offshore, while the $1.68tn that Moody’s estimates is being stashed by U.S. companies is a sum equivalent to the size of the Canadian economy|date=20 May 2016}} the Double Irish is the largest tax avoidance tool in history. In 2016, when the [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland|EU levied a €13 billion fine on Apple]], the largest tax fine in history,{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4472500/apple-eu-irish-tax-bill/|title=Apple vs the EU is the biggest tax battle in history | publisher=[[Time Magazine]]|author=RANA FOROOHAR|date=30 August 2016|quote=Ever hear of a Double Irish? It’s not a drink, but one of the dodgy tax strategies that help American companies keep their profits nearly tax free abroad. Such strategies are at the heart of what may well turn out to be the most important corporate tax case in history}} it covered the period 2004–14, during which Apple paid an Irish [[#ETR|ETR]] of <1% on [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland#Apple profits|€110.8 billion]] in Irish profits.{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.ie/2018/01/what-apple-did-next.html|title=What Apple did next|publisher=Economic Incentives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=24 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-01/pinning-down-apple-s-alleged-0-005-tax-rate-mission-impossible| title=Pinning Down Apple’s Alleged 0.005% Tax Rate Is Nearly Impossible | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=1 September 2016}} Despite the loss of taxes to the U.S. exchequer, it was the EU Commission that forced Ireland to close the Double Irish from January 2015;{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ba95cff0-4fcd-11e4-a0a4-00144feab7de | title=Brussels in crackdown on 'Double Irish' tax loophole| publisher=[[The Financial Times]]| date=October 2014|author1=Alex Barker|author2=Vincent Boland|author3=Vanessa Houlder|quote=Brussels is challenging the “Double Irish” tax avoidance measure prized by big U.S. tech and pharma groups, putting pressure on Dublin to close it down or face a full-blown investigation. [..] The initial enquiries have signalled that Brussels wants Dublin to call time on the tax gambit, which has helped Ireland become a hub for American tech and pharma giants operating in Europe.}} with closure to existing users by 2020.{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/irelands-move-to-close-the-double-irish-tax-loophole-unlikely-to-bother-apple-google-33011 | title=Ireland’s move to close the ‘Double Irish’ tax loophole unlikely to bother Apple, Google| publisher=The Guardian and University of Sydney|author=Anthony Ting|date=October 2014}} ====Single Malt==== {{Main article|Single malt arrangement}} In an October 2013 interview, [[PwC]] tax partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]] ("architect" of the Double Irish, see above), said that: "the days of the Double Irish tax scheme are numbered".{{Cite web|title = Days of 'Double Irish' tax scheme are numbered, says PwC's O'Rourke|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/days-of-double-irish-tax-scheme-are-numbered-says-pwcs-orourke-29709354.html|quote=However, Mr O'Rourke, who is also a cousin of the late Finance Minister Brian Lenihan, told Bloomberg that changes in Ireland and across the globe on tax was inevitable. Mr O'Rourke was also a member of the Government's Commission on Taxation, which sat in 2008 and 2009.|author=Colm Kelpie|publisher=[[The Irish Times]]|date=30 October 2013}} In October 2014, as the EU forced the Irish State to close the Double Irish BEPS tool, the influential U.S. [[National Tax Journal]] published an article by Jeffrey L Rubinger and Summer Lepree, showing that Irish based subsidiaries of U.S. corporations could replace the Double Irish arrangement with a new structure (now known as ''[[#Single Malt|Single Malt]]'').{{Cite web|title = Death of the "Double Irish Dutch Sandwich"? Not so Fast.|url = https://www.taxeswithoutbordersblog.com/2014/10/death-of-the-double-irish-dutch-sandwich-not-so-fast/|publisher=Taxes Without Borders|date=23 October 2014|author1=JEFFREY L. RUBINGER|author2=SUMMER AYERS LEPREE}} The Irish media picked up the article,{{Cite web|title = Multinationals replacing 'Double Irish' with new tax avoidance scheme|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/new-loophole-to-replace-the-double-irish-tax-strategy-30728951.html|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Sarah McCabe|date=9 November 2014|quote=Another sophisticated loophole in the tax system means the removal of the "Double Irish" tax-avoidance strategy won't actually have any real impact for U.S. firms in Ireland seeking to lower their tax bills. An influential U.S. tax journal has found that the Irish subsidiaries of U.S. companies can easily opt to use another loophole, known as the "check the box" rule, to enjoy the same tax benefits created by the Double Irish.}} but when an Irish [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] notified the then Finance Minister, Michael Noonan, he was told to "[[Put on the green jersey]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/dail/2017-11-23/18/|title=Dáil Éireann debate - Thursday, 23 Nov 2017|publisher=House of the Oireachtas|date=23 November 2017|quote=[[Pearse Doherty]]: It was interesting that when [MEP] Matt Carthy put that to the Minister's predecessor (Michael Noonan), his response was that this was very unpatriotic and he should wear the green jersey. That was the former Minister's response to the fact there is a major loophole, whether intentional or unintentional, in our tax code that has allowed large companies to continue to use the Double Irish [called Single Malt].}} A November 2017 report by [[Christian Aid]], titled ''Impossible Structures'', showed how quickly the Single Malt BEPS tool was replacing the Double Irish.{{Cite web|title = ‘Impossible’ structures: tax outcomes overlooked by the 2015 tax Spillover analysis|url = https://www.christianaid.ie/sites/default/files/2018-02/impossible-structures-tax-report.pdf|author=Mike Lewis|publisher=Christian Aid|date=November 2017}}{{Cite web|title = Multinationals replacing 'Double Irish' with new tax avoidance scheme|url = https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/1114/919979-multinationals-using-new-arrangement-to-reduce-tax-bill/|website = RTE News|date = 14 November 2017}}{{Cite web|title = How often is the 'Single Malt' tax loophole used? The government is finding out|url = http://www.thejournal.ie/single-malt-tax-evasion-3698512-Nov2017/|website = [[TheJournal.ie]] |date = 15 November 2017}} The report detailed Microsoft's and Allergen's schemes and extracts from advisers to their clients. In September 2018, the ''[[Irish Times]]'' revealed that U.S. medical device manufacturer [[Teleflex]], had created a Single Malt scheme in July 2018, and reduced their corporate tax rate to circa 3%;{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-s-single-malt-still-aiding-tax-avoidance-1.3640062|title=Ireland's ‘Single Malt’ still aiding tax avoidance|publisher=[[The Irish Times]]|author=Peter Hamilton|date=26 September 2018|quote=Prior to opening a Single Malt structure, Teleflex operated a Double Irish tax structure, according to Christian Aid. “Since Teleflex set up its Double Irish structure, through this and [presumably] other tax strategies its global effective tax rate has dropped to just over 3 percent,” the NGO flagged.}} and that the Irish State were keeping the matter, "under consideration". In November 2018, the Irish Government amended the Ireland–Malta tax treaty to prevent the Single Malt BEPS tool being used between Ireland and Malta (it can still be used with the UAE for example).{{cite web| url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/revenue-to-close-single-malt-tax-loophole-1.3712238 | title=Revenue to close ‘single malt’ tax loophole | publisher=[[Irish Times]] | author=Barry O'Halloran | date=28 November 2018 | quote=Using a structure dubbed the “single malt”, some US multinationals have been using Irish-registered, Malta-resident, companies to cut tax liabilities in countries where they sell their goods and services. Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe confirmed on Tuesday that a new agreement between Revenue and the Maltese tax authorities will close the loophole.}} On the same day the closure was announced, [[LinkedIn]] in Ireland, identified as a user of the Single Malt tool in 2017, announced in filings that it had sold a major IP asset to its parent, Microsoft (Ireland).{{cite web|url= https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/linkedin-s-irish-subsidiary-pays-127m-on-2-67bn-profit-1.3713088 | title=LinkedIn’s Irish subsidiary pays $127m on $2.67bn profit | publisher=[[Irish Times]] | author=Charlie Taylor|date=28 November 2018 | quote=The Irish arm of LinkedIn reported a 20 per cent rise in revenues last year and returned to the black, helped by the disposal of intellectual property assets to its parent Microsoft Ireland.}} In July 2018, it was disclosed in the Irish financial media that Microsoft (Ireland) were preparing a restructure of their Irish BEPS tools into a [[#Microsoft's Green Jersey (2018)|CAIA (or Green Jersey) Irish tax structure]]. ====Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets==== {{Main article|CAIA arrangement}} In June 2009, the Irish State established the ''Commission on Taxation'', to review Ireland's tax regime, and included [[Feargal O'Rourke]] ("architect" of the Double Irish, see above). In September 2009, the Commission recommended that the Irish State provide [[capital allowance]]s for the acquisition of [[intangible assets]], creating the ''[[CAIA arrangement|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]'' (CAIA) BEPS tool.{{cite web|url=https://researchrepository.ucd.ie/handle/10197/1447| title=Commission on Taxation report 2009|date=September 2009| publisher=UCD Archives}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1017830.shtml| title=Commission on Taxation Report Ireland 2009: Proposed property tax, a carbon tax, and domestic water charges as part of overhaul of Irish tax system|date=7 September 2009| publisher=FinFacts}} Whereas the Double Irish and Single Malt BEPS tools enable Ireland to act as a ''confidential'' "[[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFC]]" for rerouting untaxed profits to places like Bermuda (e.g. it must be ''confidential'' as higher-tax locations would not sign full tax treaties with locations like Bermuda), the CAIA BEPS tool, enables Ireland to act as the "[[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFC]]" (e.g. the terminus for untaxed profits, like Bermuda). {{quote box |width=19em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote =I cannot see a justification for giving large amounts of Irish [corporate] tax relief to the intragroup acquisition of a virtual [IP] group asset, except that it is for the purposes of facilitating [Irish] corporate tax avoidance. |salign=left |source=Professor Jim Stewart, [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]]
"MNE Tax Strategies in Ireland" (2016){{Cite web|title=MNE Tax Strategies in Ireland|url=https://www.tcd.ie/business/assets/pdf/MNE-tax-strategies-and-ireland.pdf|publisher=[[Trinity College Dublin]]|author1=Adjunct Professor Jim Stewart|date=2016}}}} CAIA uses the accepted tax concept of providing [[capital allowance]]s for the purchase of physical assets.{{efn|Most tax codes in developed countries have [[capital allowance]] programs that give tax relief on capital expenditure that is amortised over the life of the physical asset on which the capital was invested in.}} However, Ireland turns it into a BEPS tool by providing the allowances for the purchase of ''[[intangible assets]]'', and particularly ''[[intellectual property]]'' assets; and critically, where the owner of the intangible assets is a "connected party" (e.g. a Group subsidiary, often located in a tax haven); and has valued the assets for the inter-Group transaction using an Irish [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] accounting firm. CAIA ''capitalises'' the tax shield of the Double Irish, and thus materially increases the distortion of the Irish national accounts. This was shown in July 2016 when the Irish CEO had to restate Irish 2015 GDP by 34.4% due to Apple's Q1 2015 "[[leprechaun economics]]" restructure into a CAIA BEPS tool.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/world/apple-taxes-jersey.html|title=After a Tax Crackdown, Apple Found a New Shelter for Its Profits|publisher=New York Times|author=Jesse Drucker|author2=Simon Bowers|date=6 November 2017}} A June 2018 report by the EU Parliament's [[European United Left-Nordic Green Left|GUE–NGL]] body showed that Apple doubled the Irish corporate tax shield of its CAIA BEPS tool by financing the acquisition of the IP via Jersey (the report called the CAIA BEPS tool, the ''[[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]]'').{{cite web|url= https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/06/25/new-report-is-apple-paying-less-than-1-tax-in-the-eu/|title=New Report on Apple's New Irish Tax Structure|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|author=Naomi Fowler|date=25 June 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://src.bna.com/zNy|title=Apple's Irish Tax Deals|publisher=[[European United Left-Nordic Green Left]] EU Parliament|author1=Martin Brehm Christensen|author2=Emma Clancy|date=21 June 2018}} Whereas the Double Irish and Single Malt have an ETR of less than 1%, the ETR of the CAIA BEPS tool ranges from 0% to 3% depending on the date on which the CAIA tool was started (see [[#Effective tax rate (ETR)|effective tax rates]]).{{efn|name="cap"}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mhc.ie/latest/e-zines/world-ip-day-2014/P1|title=World IP Day: IRELAND'S 2.5% IP Tax Rate (Section 4.1.1)|publisher=Mason Hayes and Curran (Law Firm)|date=April 2013|quote=When combined with other features of Ireland’s IP tax regime, an effective rate as low as 2.5% can be achieved on IP related income}} ====Knowledge Development Box==== Ireland created the first OECD–compliant '''Knowledge Development Box''' ("KDB"), in the 2015 ''Finance Act'', to further support it's [[intellectual property]] [[base erosion and profit shifting|BEPS]] toolkit.{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/budget/budget-2016-do-you-know-what-the-knowledge-box-is-31576795.html|title=Do you know what the Knowledge Box is?|publisher=Irish Indepdendant|date=9 October 2015|author=Michael Cogley|quote=The initial announcement of the KDB came after the closure of the ‘double Irish’ tax loophole and while he does not see it as a knee-jerk reaction Ken Hardy, tax partner at KPMG believes it is an attempt to keep Ireland’s tax scheme as competitive as possible. However, other European countries, including Germany, have warned that these incentives should only be used as a reward for R&D investment and not as a tax avoidance to}} The KDB behaves like a [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|CAIA]] BEPS scheme with a cap of 50% (i.e. similar to getting 50%–relief against capitalised IP, for a net effective Irish tax rate of 6.25%). As with the CAIA BEPS scheme, the KDB is limited to specific "qualifying assets", however, unlike CAIA tool, these are quite narrowly defined by the 2015 ''Finance Act''.{{cite web|url = https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-29/29-03-01.pdf|title=Revenue Guidance Notes for Knowledge Development Box|publisher=Revenue Commissioners|date=2016}}{{cite web|url = http://www.bdo.ie/en-gb/insights/tax/knowledge-development-box/knowledge-development-box-(kdb)|title=Guidelines Knowledge Development Box|publisher=BDO Ireland|date=2016}} The Irish KDB was created with tight conditions to ensure OECD compliance and thus meets the OECD's "modified Nexus standard" for IP.{{cite web| url = https://www.oecd.org/ctp/beps-action-5-agreement-on-modified-nexus-approach-for-ip-regimes.pdf|title=Action 5 Agreement on Modified Nexus Approach for IP Regimes|publisher=OECD|date=2015}} This has drawn criticism from Irish tax advisory firms who feel that its use is limited to pharmaceutical (who have the most "Nexus" compliant patents/processes), and some niche sectors.{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ie/en/pages/tax/articles/knowledge-development-box-ireland.html|title=Knowledge Development Box Improvements Needed|publisher=Deloitte Ireland|date=2016}}{{cite web|url=https://home.kpmg.com/ie/en/home/insights/2016/04/kdb-best-in-class.html|title=Knowledge Development Box: Best in Class?|publisher=KPMG Ireland|date=16 April 2016}} It is expected these conditions will be relaxed over time through refinements of the 2015 ''Finance Act''; a route taken by other Irish [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS]] tools: * [[Double Irish]] – the unusual definition of tax residence was embedded in the 1997 ''Taxes and Consolidation Act'' (TCA), and expanded in 1999-2003 ''Finance Acts''.{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-02/02-02-03.pdf|title=Guidance on Tax Residence Irish Revenue|publisher=Revenue Commissioners|date=2017}} * [[Double Irish arrangement#Single malt|Single Malt]] – takes the Double Irish tax-residence concept around "management and control", and worded directly into specific bilateral tax treaties (Malta, UAE). * [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]] – introduced in the 1997 TCA but expanded in the 2009 ''Finance Act'', and made tax-free in the 2015 ''Finance Act'' for Apple.{{efn|name="cap"}} * [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPVs]] – created in the 1997 TCA with strong anti-avoidance controls, which were eroded in 2003, 2008, 2011 ''Finance Acts'' (see [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110]] article). * [[L–QIAIFs]] – [[QIAIF]]s were introduced in 2013 with the new EU [[Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive 2011|AIFMD]] regulations, but expanded in 2018 into a full [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tool]]. Irish tax-law firms expect the Irish KDB terms will be brought into alignment with the CAIA BEPS tool terms in the future.{{cite web|url=https://www.matheson.com/images/uploads/documents/KDB_Matheson.pdf|title=Knowledge Development Box Public Consultation and Observations|publisher=Matheson|date=April 2015}} ===Debt–based BEPS tools=== ====Section 110 SPV==== {{main article|Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)}} [[File:Stephen Donnelly 2016.jpg|thumb|'''[[Stephen Donnelly|Stephen Donnelly TD]]''' Estimated U.S. funds would avoid €20 billion in Irish taxes from 2016–2026 on circa €40 billion of Irish investments (2012–2016), by using Section 110 SPVs.{{cite web|url=http://stephendonnelly.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Closing-Down-Section-110-for-Vulture-Funds.pdf | title=WHY LETTING SECTION 110 SPVS OPERATE IN THE IRISH DOMESTIC ECONOMY WILL DAMAGE OUR TAX BASE AND OUR REPUTATION AS A ‘LOW-TAX’ ECONOMY | publisher=Stephen Donnelly (Dail Submission)|date=September 2016}}]] A '''Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle''' ("SPV") is an Irish [[tax resident]] company, which qualifies under Section 110 of the 1997 ''Irish Taxes Consolidation Act'' (“TCA”), by virtue of restricting itself to only holding "qualifying assets", for a special tax regime that enables the SPV to attain full tax neutrality (i.e. the SPV pays no Irish corporate taxes). It is a major Irish [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS]] tool. Section 110 was created to help [[International Financial Services Centre]] ("IFSC") legal and accounting firms compete for the administration of global [[securitisation]] deals. While they pay no Irish taxes, they contribute circa €100 million annually to the Irish economy from fees paid to the IFSC legal and accounting firms.{{cite web|url=http://www.idsa.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/IDSA_Securitisation-Industry-in-Ireland.pdf|title=Ireland: The Leading European Jurisdiction for SPVs, Structured Finance and Securitised Structures|publisher=Irish Debt Securities Association|date=2016}} IFSC firms lobbied the Irish State for [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Evolution|successive amendments]] to the Section 110 legislation, so that by 2011, Section 110 had become an Irish Debt–based BEPS tool, for avoiding tax on Irish and international assets. In 2016, it was discovered that U.S. distressed debt funds used Section 110 SPVs, structured by IFSC professional service firms,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/how-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Fcommercial-property%2Fhow-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688| title=How do vulture funds exploit tax loopholes?| publisher=Irish Times|date=17 October 2016}} to avoid material Irish taxes{{cite web|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/news/speedy-probe-into-vulture-funds-tax-urged-326329|title=Speedy probe into vulture funds' tax urged|publisher=Sunday Business Post|date=25 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/stephen-donnelly-tax-avoidance-anomaly-means-pain-for-taxpayers-34906487.html|title=Tax avoidance could run to billions|publisher=Irish Independent|date=24 bills - as State now appears to have delivered the sale of the century|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.davidmcwilliams.ie/vulture-funds-rub-salt-into-the-carcass-of-this-country/|title=Vulture funds rub salt into the carcass of this country|publisher=David McWilliams Sunday Business Post|date=1 August 2016}} while State-backed mezzanine funds were using Section 110 SPVs to lower their clients Irish corporate tax liability.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/seen-heard-state-backed-funds-using-section-110-to-slash-tax-bill-1.3141025|title=State-backed funds using Section 110 to slash tax bill|publisher=Irish Times|date=2 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/cardinal-capital-warns-of-damage-by-new-s110-35038346.html|title=Cardinal Capital warns of 'damage' by new S110 Rules=Irish Times|date=11 September 2016}} Academic studies in 2017 note that Irish Section 110 SPVs operate in a [[brass plate company|brass plate]] fashion{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/imf-queries-lawyers-and-bankers-on-hundreds-of-ifsc-boards-1.2811754|title=IMF queries lawyers and bankers on hundreds of IFSC boards|publisher=The Irish Times|date=30 September 2016}} with little regulatory oversight from the Irish Revenue or Central Bank of Ireland,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/a-third-of-ireland-s-shadow-banking-subject-to-little-or-no-oversight-1.3077931?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fa-third-of-ireland-s-shadow-banking-subject-to-little-or-no-oversight-1.3077931|title=A third of Ireland’s shadow banking subject to little or no oversight|publisher=The Irish Times|date=10 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/former-regulator-says-irish-politicians-mindless-over-ifsc-russian-risks-1.3414779?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fformer-regulator-says-irish-politicians-mindless-over-ifsc-russian-risks-1.3414779|title=Former Regulator says Irish politicians mindless of IFSC risks|publisher=The Irish Times|date=5 March 2018}} and have been attracting funds from undesirable activities (e.g. [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses|sanctioned Russian banks]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.tasc.ie/download/pdf/seminar_on_section_110_12th_jan_2017.pdf|title=‘Section 110’ Companies: A Success story for Ireland|publisher=Professor Jim Stewart Cillian Doyle| date=12 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tasc.ie/download/pdf/ireland_global_finance_and_the_russian_connection.pdf|title=Ireland, Global of Irish finance|publisher=Irish Independent|date=25 February 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/news/russian-firms-funnelled-e100bn-dublin-410840|title=How Russian Firms Funnelled
